Use Case 1: Doctor-Patient Consultation

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand your 1-year old mixed-breed dog has been referred to me due to an issue with her left eye. Can you please tell me more about the problem?
Patient: Yes, she's been having this mucopurulent discharge from her left eye for about 14 days now. It started suddenly after we took her for a walk in a meadow.
Doctor: I see. Did you notice any changes in her eye before the discharge started?
Patient: No, it was pretty much acute in onset and developed after that walk.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Has your dog received any treatment for this issue so far?
Patient: Yes, our previous veterinarian prescribed 0.3% tobramycin eye drops for her.
Doctor: How long has she been using the eye drops, and have you noticed any improvement since starting the therapy?
Patient: She's been using the drops for some days now, but we haven't seen any ocular improvement during this therapy.
Doctor: I understand. Let me perform an ophthalmic examination to get a better understanding of her condition. [After examination] I found an abundant mucopurulent to haemorrhagic discharge and a moderate conjunctival hyperemia in her left eye. I didn't see any other abnormalities in this eye. Her right eye appears to be normal.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: Based on the findings, the presumptive diagnosis is that your dog has unilateral dacryocystitis, which is an inflammation of the tear sac, likely due to a foreign body in her left eye.
Patient: Oh, I see. What can we do to help her?
Doctor: We will need to remove the foreign body and provide appropriate treatment to resolve the inflammation and infection. I will discuss the options with you and provide recommendations for follow-up care.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. We really appreciate your help with our dog's eye problem.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello Mr. Turner, I've been reviewing your case and I wanted to talk to you about your condition. You are a 65-year-old ambulatory diabetic patient with concomitant mental illness and alcoholism. It seems that you've had some difficulty sticking to your diabetic regime in the past. Can you share more about that?
Patient: Yeah, I had a tough time managing my diabetes. I guess I just didn't take it seriously enough.
Doctor: I understand, Mr. Turner. Over a 21-month period, you had 44 emergency department visits and 27 hospitalizations, with over half of those hospitalizations being in the Intensive Care Unit for diabetic ketoacidosis. It became medically necessary to involve Home-Based Primary Care (HBPC) to help you manage your condition better. How have you been feeling since the HBPC visits started?
Patient: Oh, those visits have made a huge difference! I feel much more engaged in my care now, and I'm starting to understand how important it is to manage my diabetes.
Doctor: That's great to hear. I see that the HBPC team consulted behavioral health clinicians to help you with your mental health and alcoholism as well. Are you finding their support helpful?
Patient: Yes, they've been really helpful. I feel like I'm finally getting the support I need to deal with everything going on in my life.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. I also noticed that you got new glasses to help you read your insulin syringes. Has that made a difference in your ability to manage your diabetes?
Patient: Absolutely! I can finally see the markings on the syringes clearly, so I'm more confident in taking the right amount of insulin.
Doctor: That's excellent, Mr. Turner. It seems like after the house calls were initiated, your adherence to your diabetic regime and your overall quality of life dramatically improved. In fact, you've only had one hospitalization over the next two years. How do you feel about your progress?
Patient: I'm really happy with how things are going. It's been a big change, but I feel like I'm finally in control of my health.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. HBPC programs like the one you're participating in are increasing in prevalence across the United States, thanks to health systems promoting value-based care. These programs aim to provide high-quality, compassionate care in the home for patients with the highest level of medical need, while also achieving cost savings.
Patient: That's good to know. It's definitely been a lifesaver for me.
Doctor: Yes, these programs can be quite beneficial. They come in different models, including hospital-based, government-run, and free-standing programs. They often involve an interdisciplinary team approach, and some even have a financial entity that takes on the risk for patient care, which can lead to shared cost-savings as a result of better care.
Patient: Wow, I didn't realize there were so many different types of programs. I'm just grateful I got the help I needed.
Doctor: We're glad to help, Mr. Turner. Just remember to continue following your diabetic regime and the advice of your healthcare team. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate all the support I've gotten, and I'll do my best to stay on track with my health.

S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

Doctor: That's great to hear. I see that the HBPC team consulted behavioral health clinicians to help you with your mental health and alcoholism as well. Are you finding their support helpful?
Patient: Yes, they've been really helpful. I feel like I'm finally getting the support I need to deal with everything going on in my life.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. I also noticed that you got new glasses to help you read your insulin syringes. Has that made a difference in your ability to manage your diabetes?
Patient: Absolutely! I can finally see the markings on the syringes clearly, so I'm more confident in taking the right amount of insulin.
Doctor: That's excellent, Mr. Turner. It seems like after the house calls were initiated, your adherence to your diabetic regime and your overall quality of life dramatically improved. In fact, you've only had one hospitalization over the next two years. How do you feel about your progress?
Patient: I'm really happy with how things are going. It's been a big change, but I feel like I'm finally in control of my health.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that, Mr. Turner. HBPC programs like the one you're participating in are increasing in prevalence across the United States, thanks to health systems promoting value-based care. These programs aim to provide high-quality, compassionate care in the home for patients with the highest level of medical need, while also achieving cost savings.
Patient: That's good to know. It's definitely been a lifesaver for me.
Doctor: Yes, these programs can be quite beneficial. They come in different models, including hospital-based, government-run, and free-standing programs. They often involve an interdisciplinary team approach, and some even have a financial entity that takes on the risk for patient care, which can lead to shared cost-savings as a result of better care.
Patient: Wow, I didn't realize there were so many different types of programs. I'm just grateful I got the help I needed.
Doctor: We're glad to help, Mr. Turner. Just remember to continue following your diabetic regime and the advice of your healthcare team. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate all the support I've gotten, and I'll do my best to stay on track with my health.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you were referred to our department due to a several-week history of right inguinal pain and discomfort in your right femur that worsened with movement. Can you describe the pain and discomfort you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yes, the pain in my right groin area has been bothering me for a few weeks now. It gets worse whenever I move, and I also feel some discomfort in my right thigh.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We conducted laboratory tests, and your white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels were normal. We also performed ultrasound and computed tomography examinations, which indicated a vermiform appendix in an inguinal hernia sac. However, there were no remarkable findings of inflammation in the appendix (Fig. a, b).
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what's the diagnosis then?
Doctor: Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with an Amyand's hernia (AH) without appendicitis. We attempted a reduction of the hernia under ultrasound, but it was unsuccessful. Therefore, we planned a combined totally extraperitoneal (TEP) mesh repair and laparoscopic appendectomy after laparoscopic reduction.
Patient: Hmm, okay. What does that procedure involve?
Doctor: First, you will be placed in a supine position and undergo general anesthesia by tracheal intubation. We will first perform a laparoscopic transabdominal approach after establishing pneumoperitoneum. A 5-mm direct umbilical trocar and a needle forceps (Endo Relief™) will be introduced into the upper right abdominal quadrant to inspect the hernia canal for the absence of appendicitis and reduce the appendix laparoscopically.
Patient: Alright. What happens after that?
Doctor: During the inspection, we found a 3 × 2 cm right external inguinal hernia defect with the appendix, but no other intra-abdominal pathology was identified. We will pull the vermiform appendix out and place it in the abdominal cavity without tearing it. After that, we will reduce the hernia sac into the abdomen via the laparoscopic TEP approach.
Patient: Okay, and then what?
Doctor: You will be placed in a 30° Trendelenburg position. We will lateralize the rectus muscle and insert a Covidien Balloon Dissector preperitoneally from the umbilical incision of the skin to the symphysis pubis. The balloon will be insufflated to open the extraperitoneal area. We will then introduce additional trocars: a 12-mm trocar in the initial umbilical incision of the skin and anterior right fascia of the rectus, and a 5-mm trocar at the symphysis.
Patient: I understand. What can I expect after the surgery?
Doctor: After the surgery, we will monitor your recovery and address any potential complications. It is important for you to follow our post-operative care instructions, which may include pain management, wound care, and activity restrictions.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns during your recovery, please don't hesitate to contact us. We're here to help you every step of the way.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were admitted to our hospital with the chief complaint of jaundice in your skin and sclera, along with epigastric pain for the past two weeks. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The yellowing and pain have been bothering me a lot.
Doctor: I understand. We've conducted several examinations to determine the cause, including enhanced abdominal and pelvic CT scans, a chest X-ray, an abdominal ultrasound, tumor markers, liver and renal function tests, and coagulation function tests. Let me go over the results with you.
Patient: Okay, please do.
Doctor: The CT scans revealed a low-density mass of 4.0 cm in diameter located in the uncinate process of your pancreas. Additionally, your intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts are obviously dilated, and your pancreatic duct is slightly dilated as well. The non-contrast CT scan showed calcification within the mass, and the contrast CT showed that the enhancement of the tumor is similar to the surrounding normal pancreatic parenchyma. Here's a figure for you to see (Fig.).
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means there's a growth in your pancreas that could be contributing to your symptoms. Now, let's go over your laboratory data. Your white blood cell count, red blood cell count, and hemoglobin levels are within the normal ranges. However, your AFP level is elevated at 71.5 ng/mL, while the normal range is less than 8.1 ng/mL.
Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Additionally, your carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is within the normal range at 2.0 ng/mL, but your carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) is significantly elevated at 437.2 U/mL, with the normal range being 0-37 U/mL. Your aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT) levels are also elevated, at 51 U/L and 151 U/L, respectively.
Patient: Wow, that's quite high.
Doctor: Yes, it is. Furthermore, your total bilirubin (TBIL) and direct bilirubin (DBIL) levels are also elevated, at 281.2 μmol/L and 212.6 μmol/L, respectively. These results, along with the imaging findings, led us to suspect an incorrect diagnosis of pancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasm before the operation.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that we initially suspected a specific type of pancreatic tumor, but further examinations and test results may require us to revise our diagnosis. Our team will continue to investigate and determine the appropriate course of action.
Patient: Alright. What's the next step?
Doctor: We will need to perform additional tests and possibly a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Once we have a definitive diagnosis, we can then discuss treatment options and develop a care plan tailored to your specific needs.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your thorough explanation.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll keep you informed and work together to address your health concerns. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or need assistance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello! I see from your history that you've been dealing with Ph+ precursor B-cell ALL for two years now. Can you tell me about the symptoms that led you to the emergency department back in June 2015?
Patient: Yeah, I had been feeling really tired and lethargic for a couple of weeks. I also had backache, leg, and rib pain that was so bad that even opioids didn't help.
Doctor: I see. Your blood counts at that time showed leukocytosis with a white cell count of 67 × 10^9 cells/l and 34% lymphoblasts measured by flow cytometry. Your hemoglobin was 12.3 g/dl and your platelet count was at 49 × 10^9/l. A bone marrow aspirate and biopsy confirmed that you had a precursor B-cell ALL, Ph+ (t 9; 22). You were then enrolled in the UKALL14, version 6 Protocol, which is a five-drug induction regimen designed for adults with de novo ALL between 25 and 65 years. 
Patient: Yeah, I remember that. They gave me a bunch of medications.
Doctor: Yes, during Induction Phase I, you received PEG-ASP (1000 IU/m2) on days 4 and 18, daunorubicin 30 mg/m2 and vincristine 1.4 mg/m2 on days 1, 8, 15, and 22, dexamethasone 10 mg/m2 on days 1–4, 8–11, 15–18, and intrathecal methotrexate (ITMTX) 12.5 mg on day 14. You were also given continuous imatinib 400 mg, which was later escalated to 600 mg daily throughout your induction treatment.
Patient: That's right. And then I had another round of treatment.
Doctor: Correct. During Phase II induction, you were given cyclophosphamide 1000 mg/m2 on days 1 and 15, Ara-C 75 mg/m2 on days 2–5, 9–12, 16–19, and 23–26, mercaptopurine 60 mg/m2 throughout, and intrathecal methotrexate on days 1, 8, 15, and 22.
Patient: So, what happened after that?
Doctor: After Phase II induction, you achieved a complete molecular remission with negative BCR-ABL1 p190 transcripts, as determined by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). However, you did experience some complications, including constipation, febrile neutropenia, and pneumonia.
Patient: Yeah, that was a tough time. What came next?
Doctor: To consolidate your remission, you underwent myeloablative conditioning, which included cyclophosphamide and total body irradiation (TBI). This was followed by a stem cell transplant to help rebuild your immune system and fight off any remaining cancer cells.
Patient: I remember that. It was quite an intense treatment.
Doctor: Yes, it can be. But the good news is that you achieved a complete molecular remission, which is a great outcome. It's important to continue with regular follow-ups and monitoring to ensure that your condition remains stable and any potential complications are addressed promptly.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I understand you've been experiencing some symptoms recently. Can you tell me about them?
Patient: Yeah, for the past 2 weeks, I've had a productive cough, fever, shortness of breath, and I've been feeling really weak and tired.
Doctor: I see. Let's go over your past medical history. You have coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, interstitial lung disease, and obstructive sleep apnea, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: On presentation, your vitals showed a blood pressure of 77/35 mmHg, heart rate of 122 bpm, respiratory rate of 38 bpm, a temperature of 102 F, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 15 L of oxygen. We also noted that you were diaphoretic, with decreased breath sounds in the right lung field, and on palpation of your abdomen, there was right upper quadrant fullness.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Your initial laboratory studies showed elevated white blood cells at 22.6 × 109/L with neutrophilia, bicarbonate at 21 mmol/L, lactic acid at 6.5 mmol/L, anion gap at 17, ALT at 71 IU/L, AST at 69 IU/L, and ALP at 450 IU/L. Your ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Your CXR showed an acute right pleural effusion.
Patient: Hmm, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Due to your respiratory failure, we had to intubate you. We also started you on antibiotics - piperacillin-tazobactam and azithromycin - and intravenous normal saline. However, there was no improvement in your blood pressure, so we had to start you on intravenous vasopressor support with norepinephrine and vasopressin. You were admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Because of the right upper quadrant fullness, elevated liver enzymes, and fever, we performed an abdominal ultrasound, which showed an acute complex heterogeneous hypoechoic mass-like lesion in your right hepatic lobe, measuring 8 × 7 × 6 cm.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: To better understand the lesion, we did a CT scan of your abdomen. The CT showed a complex low-density right hepatic lobe subcapsular lesion measuring 13 × 8 × 7 cm, directly abutting the right anterior diaphragm. We also found diffuse gross gallbladder wall thickening with cholelithiasis and a moderate right pleural effusion.
Patient: Oh, wow.
Doctor: To manage the pleural effusion, the patient underwent chest tube placement.
Patient: What happens next?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor you closely in the ICU and manage your symptoms and the underlying issues. We may need to consult with other specialists and may consider further interventions based on your progress and the findings so far.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you or your family have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you through this.

Doctor: Due to your respiratory failure, we had to intubate you. We also started you on antibiotics - piperacillin-tazobactam and azithromycin - and intravenous normal saline. However, there was no improvement in your blood pressure, so we had to start you on intravenous vasopressor support with norepinephrine and vasopressin. You were admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Because of the right upper quadrant fullness, elevated liver enzymes, and fever, we performed an abdominal ultrasound, which showed an acute complex heterogeneous hypoechoic mass-like lesion in your right hepatic lobe, measuring 8 × 7 × 6 cm.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: To better understand the lesion, we did a CT scan of your abdomen. The CT showed a complex low-density right hepatic lobe subcapsular lesion measuring 13 × 8 × 7 cm, directly abutting the right anterior diaphragm. We also found diffuse gross gallbladder wall thickening with cholelithiasis and a moderate right pleural effusion.
Patient: Oh, wow.
Doctor: To manage the pleural effusion, the patient underwent chest tube placement.
Patient: What happens next?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor you closely in the ICU and manage your symptoms and the underlying issues. We may need to consult with other specialists and may consider further interventions based on your progress and the findings so far.
Patient: Alright, thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you or your family have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask. We're here to help you through this.

SOAP Note:
S: 
- Patient is a 60-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, interstitial lung disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.
- Patient presents with a productive cough, fever, shortness of breath, and weakness.
- Patient has a history of right upper quadrant fullness, elevated liver enzymes, and fever.

O: 
- Patient's vital signs: blood pressure of 77/35 mmHg, heart rate of 122 bpm, respiratory rate of 38 bpm, temperature of 102 F, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 15 L of oxygen.
- Patient's physical examination: diaphoretic, with decreased breath sounds in the right lung field, and right upper quadrant fullness.
- Patient's laboratory studies: elevated white blood cells at 22.6 × 109/L with neutrophilia, bicarbonate at 21 mmol/L, lactic acid at 6.5 mmol/L, anion gap at 17, ALT at 71 IU/L, AST at 69 IU/L, and ALP at 450 IU/L.
- Patient's ECG: atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response.
- Patient's CXR: acute right pleural effusion.
- Patient's abdominal ultrasound: acute complex heterogeneous hypoechoic mass-like lesion in the right hepatic lobe.
- Patient's CT scan: complex low-density right hepatic lobe subcapsular lesion measuring 13 × 8 × 7 cm, directly abutting the right anterior diaphragm.
- Patient's chest tube placement: to manage the right pleural effusion.

A: 
- Diagnosis: acute complex heterogeneous hypoechoic mass-like lesion in the right hepatic lobe, with right upper quadrant fullness, elevated liver enzymes, and fever.
- Differential diagnosis: acute liver failure, acute pancreatitis, acute cholecystitis, acute appendicitis, acute myocardial infarction, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and acute pulmonary embolism.

P: 
- Plan: 
1. Intubate the patient and start antibiotics - piperacillin-tazobactam and azithromycin.
2. Start intravenous normal saline and vasopressor

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, S.B. I see that you were prescribed rivaroxaban for atrial fibrillation in the past. Can you tell me more about why you stopped the treatment?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I stopped taking rivaroxaban because I saw some television advertisements that raised concerns about the risks.
Doctor: I understand your concern. Unfortunately, several months after stopping rivaroxaban therapy, you suffered an ischemic cerebral vascular accident (CVA) which converted to a hemorrhagic stroke 2 days later. That happened 2 years ago, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. It was a difficult time for me and my family.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. These events resulted in left hemiplegia, which I can see from your medical report. Now, you've been taking warfarin for your atrial fibrillation and have been monitored at your local anticoagulation clinic for about a year, correct?
Patient: Yes, doctor. I've been going there for regular checkups and they monitor my international normalized ratio (INR) levels.
Doctor: That's good to hear. It seems that during your year of warfarin therapy, you reported regularly to the anticoagulation clinic for INR monitoring, with 5- to 8-week follow-up intervals. Most of the time, your INR remained within the prescribed therapeutic range of 2-3. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I also see that you've been suffering from numerous sequelae related to your CVA, and you decided to pursue hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) to improve your clinical status and quality of life. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I wanted to try something that might help me feel better and improve my quality of life.
Doctor: I understand. Now, prior to starting your HBOT, you went to the anticoagulation clinic for a regular follow-up, and it was determined that your INR was elevated at 3.5. During the discussion, your son, who is also your caregiver, mentioned that you would be undergoing 1-hour HBOT sessions, five times a week, for a total duration of 6 weeks. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. We've been traveling a long distance to get to the treatment site, and we didn't want to alter the warfarin dose at that time.
Doctor: It's important to consider the increased risk of bleeding events when your INR is out of range. I see that your next INR reading was slightly out of range at 3.2, and no dose change was made. At that time, you were 3 weeks into your HBOT treatment plan without any bleeding complications noted. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, so far I haven't had any complications from the treatment.
Doctor: That's good to hear. It's important to continue monitoring your INR closely and discussing any concerns with your healthcare provider. If you ever have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your guidance and support.

Follow-up exercises:
1. What are the potential risks of stopping rivaroxaban therapy without consulting a healthcare provider?
Solution: Stopping rivaroxaban therapy without consulting a healthcare provider can increase the risk of blood clots and stroke. Rivaroxaban is a blood thinner that helps prevent blood clots, and abruptly stopping the medication can lead to a rebound effect where blood clotting is increased. This can result in serious complications such as stroke, heart attack, or deep vein thrombosis.

2. Why is it important to monitor INR levels during warfarin therapy?
Solution: Monitoring INR levels during warfarin therapy is important to ensure that the medication is working effectively and within the prescribed therapeutic range

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 19-year-old Indian male. What brings you here today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss lately.
Doctor: I see. Let's run some tests to find out what's causing these symptoms. 
(After running tests)
Doctor: Based on the test results, you have been diagnosed with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2N0M0). To treat this, you will need to undergo a left hemicolectomy, colocolic, and jejunojejunal anastomosis.
Patient: Okay, Doctor. I trust your judgment.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: Your surgery went well, but unfortunately, seven days postoperatively, you developed an anastomotic leak. We had to reoperate to fix the issue.
Patient: Oh no, that's not good. What's next, Doctor?
Doctor: After the second surgery, you were moved to the ICU. On day 2, your condition worsened, and you required high-dose vasopressor. We also had to put you on mechanical ventilation for pulmonary edema.
Patient: Hmm, so what did the echocardiography show?
Doctor: The 2D-echocardiography revealed severely depressed left ventricular function. The findings include global hypokinesia in the anteroseptal wall, anterior wall, and intraventricular septum. Your left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is 15-20%. There's also mild mitral regurgitation, mild tricuspid regurgitation, and no pulmonary artery hypertension. The intra-ventricular and intra-atrial septum are intact, and there's no pericardial effusion, clot, or vegetation seen.
Patient: What about the ECG results?
Doctor: The ECG showed sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 150 bpm, poor R wave progression, and nonspecific ST-T changes. Your Troponin I level is 1.69 ng/mL, CPK-MB is 5.2 ng/mL, and BNP is 2000 pg/mL.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: We considered the possibility of acute coronary syndrome as a differential, but septic myocarditis is more strongly suspected. 
Patient: What's the treatment plan then?
Doctor: We've started you on daily aspirin 75 mg, clopidogrel 75 mg, injection fondaparinux 2.5 mg, and injection torsemide 20 mg thrice daily. 
Patient: I understand. What happened on day 3?
Doctor: On day 3, your hypotension and metabolic acidosis worsened despite high dosages of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dobutamine, as well as a stress dose of hydrocortisone. Your tachycardia was bothersome, and you had chilled peripheries and seemed to be maximally vasoconstricted. Your urine output started falling, so we escalated your antibiotics according to pus culture sensitivity reports.
Patient: Is there anything else that needs to be done?
Doctor: Considering cardiogenic shock as the primary cause of your condition, we've planned to put in an IABP, without wasting any more time.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

- Management of cardiogenic shock: IABP insertion.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been experiencing some difficulty swallowing and pain when swallowing for about two months now. I also feel like solid foods are getting stuck in my neck.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any choking or gagging?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Alright. Have you had any tests or treatments for this issue?
Patient: Yes, I had neck ultrasonography at my primary care doctor's office, and they found a 6.1-cm cyst. They thought it was an infection and treated me with antibiotics, but my symptoms didn't improve.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for the information. Have you had any other health problems in the past?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of hypertension.
Doctor: Do you have any other complaints or any history of immunosuppressive disorders like HIV/AIDS, celiac disease, or inflammatory bowel disease?
Patient: No, I don't. And I haven't had any nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, or weight loss either.
Doctor: Good to know. What about your family history? Is there any history of cancer?
Patient: No, my family history is negative for cancer.
Doctor: Thank you. I'd like to perform a physical examination now. *After the examination* I found a large, tender, and palpable neck mass. We'll need to run some laboratory tests and imaging studies to investigate further.
*After receiving test results*
Doctor: Your laboratory studies, including hematology, serum biochemistry, and urine analysis, are all within normal limits. However, the computed tomography (CT) scan of your head and neck showed a 7.3 × 3.1 × 6.6-cm mass in your neck, which is inseparable from your cervical esophagus. There is no apparent bone compression.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also performed a barium esophagogram which showed an intact esophageal mucosa, but there is marked narrowing of the cervical part of your esophagus. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy confirmed the tumor-related esophageal luminal narrowing. We performed an EUS-guided FNA, but it came back inconclusive.
Patient: So, what do we do now?
Doctor: Our interventional radiology team performed a biopsy of the neck mass. The histopathologic analysis showed malignant lymphocytes with moderately abundant cytoplasm and round-to-ovoid nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemical examination was positive for CD20 and CD10 antibodies, and staining was diffusely positive for BCL6 antibody.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: Based on these findings, you have been diagnosed with primary esophageal lymphoma. We will need to discuss your treatment options and create a plan moving forward.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you have a history of alcohol abuse, and you've presented to the gastroenterology department. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, I've been suffering from severe epigastric pain and nausea for the past two days.
Doctor: I see. Based on your symptoms and your history, I would like to run some laboratory tests to see if there might be any issue with your pancreas. The findings may help us determine if you have pancreatitis or not.
Patient: Okay, that makes sense.
[After the tests]
Doctor: Your laboratory findings were suspicious for pancreatitis, so we decided to proceed with a computed tomography (CT) examination. The CT scan showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space as well as in the anterior, posterior, and lateroconal fascia. There were no signs of chronic pancreatitis or vascular complications, but you did have two similar episodes of acute tail pancreatitis in the following months.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: In September 2009, you presented with vague epigastric pain lasting several weeks. Your serum amylase and lipase levels were normal, but your cholestatic parameters were mildly elevated. We performed a magnetic resonance (MR) study, which demonstrated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung's duct. No other abnormalities were found, but further examinations revealed a Helicobacter pylori gastritis.
Patient: Hmm, that's concerning.
Doctor: In February 2012, you presented again to the gastroenterologist with epigastric and left upper quadrant pain. Your laboratory findings were not suspect for acute pancreatitis. However, we performed a contrast-enhanced CT scan to evaluate the known chronic pancreatitis and other potential causes of your pain.
Patient: And what did the scan find?
Doctor: The CT scan revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail, consisting of a conglomeration of small hypervascular spots and blood vessels. We needed to differentiate between a vascular malformation and a hypervascular pancreatic tumor, such as an islet cell tumor or a hypervascular metastasis.
Patient: How did you do that?
Doctor: We performed a contrast-enhanced MR study which showed a focal area of heterogeneous contrast enhancement without an apparent nodular component. The subsequent angiography revealed two large feeding arteries in the early arterial phase, followed by a racemose vascular network, an early transient dense parenchyma stain in the early portal phase, and early wash-out of the lesion in the portal phase.
Doctor: Based on these findings, we diagnosed you with a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation.
Patient: What does that mean for me, and what do I need to do now?
Doctor: It means that there is an abnormal connection between the arteries and veins in your pancreas. We will need to monitor your condition closely and discuss potential treatment options with you. Please make sure to follow up with us regularly to ensure proper care and management.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to follow up with you as instructed.

A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]

- Mild cholestatic parameters.
- Moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung's duct.
- No other abnormalities found.
- Helicobacter pylori gastritis.
- Contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail.
- Need to differentiate between a vascular malformation and a hypervascular pancreatic tumor.
- Angiography shows two large feeding arteries in the early arterial phase, followed by a racemose vascular network, an early transient dense parenchyma stain in the early portal phase, and early wash-out of the lesion in the portal phase.
- Diagnosis of pancreatic arteriovenous malformation.

A: 
- Diagnosis of pancreatic arteriovenous malformation.

P: 
- Treatment recommendations:
  - Close monitoring of condition.
  - Regular follow-up appointments.
  - Discuss potential treatment options with the patient.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, I'm Dr. Smith. I heard you were brought to the emergency department by ambulance yesterday due to altered mental status. Can you tell me what happened?
Patient: Hi, Dr. Smith. My mother found me in my apartment yesterday feeling very confused and lethargic. She called emergency services because she was worried about me.
Doctor: I see. According to your mother, you mentioned taking a large amount of ibuprofen in a suicide attempt earlier that day. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I took around 300 tablets of 200 mg ibuprofen, so it must have been around 60,000 mg in total.
Doctor: That's a very high dose. Do you have any known allergies to medications?
Patient: No, I don't have any allergies to medications.
Doctor: I understand you have a medical history of depression, asthma, alcohol abuse, and prior drug abuse, including cocaine, Percocet, and intravenous heroin. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I completed a drug rehabilitation program six months ago and haven't been using illegal drugs since then. I still smoke half a pack of cigarettes a day and occasionally drink alcohol with friends.
Doctor: It's good to hear you've been staying away from illegal drugs. I also see that you have a surgical history of breast reduction surgery. Now, let's talk about your family's medical history. Your father has hypertension, your mother has non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and your aunt has cryptogenic cirrhosis, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: When you were brought in, your vital signs were temperature 98 degrees Fahrenheit, pulse 111 beats per minute, blood pressure 109/66 mmHg, respiratory rate 17, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Your physical exam showed lethargy, but nothing else significant. Your initial complete blood count (CBC) and basic metabolic panel (BMP) were within normal limits. 
Patient: Okay, so what happened after that?
Doctor: To protect your airway, you were intubated and admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further treatment. Due to the ibuprofen overdose, you were emergently hemodialyzed overnight.
Patient: So, what's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We'll continue to monitor your condition closely and provide any necessary treatments. It's crucial that you follow up with your primary care physician and mental health provider to ensure proper care and support.
Patient: Thank you, Dr. Smith. I appreciate all the help.
generated_soap:
S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

Follow-up exercises:
1. What are the potential complications of an ibuprofen overdose?
Solution: Potential complications of an ibuprofen overdose include gastrointestinal bleeding, kidney damage, liver damage, and respiratory depression.
2. How does hemodialysis help in the treatment of an ibuprofen overdose?
Solution: Hemodialysis helps in the treatment of an ibuprofen overdose by removing the drug from the patient's bloodstream through a process of filtration and diffusion.
3. What are some preventive measures that can be taken to avoid ibuprofen overdose?
Solution: Some preventive measures to avoid ibuprofen overdose include following the recommended dosage instructions, not exceeding the maximum daily dose, avoiding combining ibuprofen with other medications that contain ibuprofen, and seeking medical advice before starting any new medications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello! I see you have a history of age-related macular degeneration. What brings you to the clinic today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was told to come in for a routine dilated fundus exam.
Doctor: Alright, let's start by checking your visual acuity. Your Snellen visual acuity is 20/100 OD in your right eye and count fingers OS in your left eye. I'll now perform the exam.
Patient: Okay, Doctor.
Doctor: I'm noticing some concerning findings. There is end-stage AMD in your left eye and subretinal hemorrhage in your right eye. I think we should refer you for an ocular ultrasound.
Patient: Hmm, alright.
*After the ocular ultrasound*
Doctor: The results show that you have subretinal hemorrhage in your right eye, secondary to progression of your macular degeneration. We will initiate Anti-VEGF treatment and continue it for several months.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
*After several months*
Doctor: Your recent tests show a choroidal lesion measuring 14.5 × 14.6 mm in basal dimension with a thickness of 6.4 mm. There is low to medium reflectivity, moderate irregularity, and trace spontaneous vascularity. These findings are consistent with a clinical diagnosis of choroidal melanoma.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We need to do a liver ultrasound to check for any lesions and further evaluate your condition.
*After liver ultrasound*
Doctor: The liver ultrasound showed questionable focal lesions, so we'll need a CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis for further evaluation.
Patient: Alright, let's do it.
*After CT scan and ocular re-evaluation*
Doctor: The staging CT scan and ocular ultrasound (Fig.) were negative for metastatic disease and extrascleral extension. However, an MRI of the orbits with contrast showed a subcentimeter region of abnormal contrast enhancement extending into the adjacent retro-bulbar fat, which is suspicious for scleral invasion and small extrascleral lesional extension (Fig.).
Patient: So, what does that mean?
Doctor: It means there's a possibility of the melanoma spreading beyond the eye, but we'll need to monitor it closely.
*Several days later*
Patient: Doctor, I've been having complaints of right eye pain. It feels like a monotonous friction-like pain.
Doctor: Let's examine your eye. Your visual acuity is now no light perception (NLP) OD in your right eye, and your intraocular pressure is 28 OD. There is diffuse hemorrhage in the anterior chamber and no view into the posterior pole due to vitreous hemorrhage. We'll need to perform a B-scan ocular ultrasound during this visit.
*After B-scan ocular ultrasound*
Doctor: The B-scan results show hemorrhagic choroidal detachment. We'll need to discuss further treatment options and monitor your condition closely.
Patient: Okay, thank you for your help, Doctor.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

Exercise 1: What is the purpose of a SOAP note?
Answer: The purpose of a SOAP note is to provide a structured and organized record of a patient's visit, including their subjective findings, objective findings, assessment, and plan.

Exercise 2: What is the difference between a SOAP note and a medical record?
Answer: A SOAP note is a record of a specific patient's visit, while a medical record contains the entire history of a patient's medical care.

Exercise 3: What are the four components of a SOAP note?
Answer: The four components of a SOAP note are Subjective, Objective, Assessment, and Plan.

Exercise 4: Why is it important to use a standardized format for SOAP notes?
Answer: Using a standardized format for SOAP notes ensures that all healthcare providers have access to the same information, making it easier to communicate and coordinate care.

Exercise 5: What is the purpose of a B-scan ocular ultrasound?
Answer: A B-scan ocular ultrasound is used to visualize the retina and choroid in real-time, allowing for the detection of any abnormalities or changes in the eye.

Exercise 6: What is the purpose of a liver ultrasound?
Answer: A liver ultrasound is used to evaluate the liver for any abnormalities or lesions, such as tumors or cysts.

Exercise 7: What is the purpose of a CT scan?
Answer: A CT scan is used to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures, allowing for the detection of any abnormalities or changes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I am a 26-year-old primigravida and I am 23 weeks pregnant. I have a distension in my abdomen that's worrying me.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Yes, two years ago, I had a left salpingo-oopherectomy for an ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma. I received six cycles of combined chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel afterward and was advised to use contraception. I didn't follow up after that, and now I am pregnant.
Doctor: Thank you for providing that information. Let's do an abdomen examination to check for any issues. *After examining the patient* It appears that there is some ascites and your uterus is about the size of a 24 weeks pregnancy with palpable fetal parts. We should also do an ultrasound examination to investigate further.
Patient: Okay, what did you find in the ultrasound?
Doctor: The ultrasound shows an intra-uterine pregnancy of 23 weeks and a right ovarian mass of 12.8 x 8.8 cm with solid and cystic areas containing free fluid with internal echoes. Your CA-125 level is also elevated at 80 IU/ml. Based on these findings, it seems like you have recurrent ovarian cancer during your pregnancy.
Patient: Oh no, what are my options?
Doctor: Ideally, we would recommend surgical management to address the cancer. However, I understand that you declined this option. Instead, we started you on two courses of chemotherapy with a single dose of carboplatin 450mg intravenously at three-week intervals.
Patient: Yes, I remember that. But I couldn't do the third course because my liver function tests were not good.
Doctor: That's correct. Unfortunately, the ascites has been progressive, which has led to maternal respiratory distress and fetal growth restriction and oligohydroamnios. We have decided to plan an elective Cesarean section with staging laparotomy at 34 weeks for the breech presentation with decreased liquor and gross ascites, after completion of steroid cover.
Patient: What will happen during the surgery?
Doctor: Intraoperatively, we will drain the hemorrhagic ascetic fluid, which could be around 20 liters. We will also examine the omentum, which appears to be agglutinated over the intestine with deposits present over the uterus. The right ovary has been replaced by a 15x15 cm tumor with rupture and hemorrhage.
Patient: Will my baby be okay?
Doctor: We will do our best to ensure a safe delivery. Your healthy baby girl was born weighing 2.3 kg with APGAR scores of 6/10 and 8/10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The placenta appeared normal at the time of delivery.
Patient: What else was done during the surgery?
Doctor: We performed a total abdominal hysterectomy with right salpingo-oopherectomy, infracolic omentectomy, and appendectomy. Peritoneal washings were collected and multiple peritoneal biopsies were taken for further evaluation.
Patient: I see. What should I expect in terms of follow-up care?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your recovery and the results of the biopsies. Additionally, regular check-ups and imaging will be needed to assess the effectiveness of the treatment and to watch for any signs of recurrence. It is important to follow up with your healthcare team and stay proactive in your care.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm reviewing your case and it looks like you're a 52-year-old gentleman, asymptomatic and a nonsmoker, without any comorbidities but with class II obesity, as your BMI is 37.7. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: You were referred to us from the lung cancer screening program. The high-resolution chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed a 1.5 cm mixed ground glass opacity (GGO) with a larger solid component in your right middle lobe (RML). Have you experienced any symptoms related to this?
Patient: No, I haven't felt anything unusual.
Doctor: Okay. The nodule increased in size at the follow-up CT scan, so we decided to resect the middle lobe anatomically using subcostal access. You were given general anesthesia with double lumen endotracheal intubation and placed in a lateral decubitus position, at dorsal decubitus 40 degrees. Does that sound familiar?
Patient: Yes, I remember that part.
Doctor: We made a 5 cm oblique incision parallel to the costal arch, and then the subcutaneous tissue and rectus abdominis were dissected along the subcostal margin. We detached the xiphoid process and pericardiophrenic fatty tissue. A subcostal tunnel was bluntly dissected using a finger until the mediastinal pleura was opened at the cardiophrenic angle. We then placed a covidien wound protector (WPLGR914). 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: We used a thoracoscopic lens with a 30° angle (Olympus, Melville, NY) to examine the interlobar fissure. Lobectomy was performed as shown in the video [subcostal right middle lobe lobectomy video]. We also carried out a systematic mediastinal lymph nodes dissection, which included stations 2, 4 right paratracheal, 9, 10, 11, 12, and subcarinal lymph nodes. We used long and sturdier VATS instruments, as well as curved tip stapler technology that aids in allowing passage around vascular structures. 
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We didn't put any extra ports, and the entire operative time was only 30 minutes. After completing the procedure, we inserted a 28 F chest tube through the same subcostal wound.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: You were given routine venous thromboembolism prophylaxis (6000 i.u UFH) 12 hours after the operation. How are you feeling now?
Patient: I feel much better, thank you.
Doctor: Great! It's essential to monitor your recovery and follow up on any necessary appointments. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.
Patient: Thank you, I appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the Department of Neurosurgery today. What brings you in?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having this left facial droop and some spasms on the same side.
Doctor: I see. Other than the facial droop and spasm, do you have any relevant past medical or surgical history?
Patient: No, I don't have any other medical or surgical history.
Doctor: Alright. Based on your symptoms and our examination, it appears you have an unruptured right middle cerebral artery (MCA) aneurysm. We will need to admit you to the hospital for a right-sided craniotomy to clip the aneurysm.
Patient: Oh, okay. What does that procedure involve?
Doctor: The procedure is called a pterional craniotomy, and it will be performed under general anesthesia. During the surgery, we will use intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring methods to ensure your safety.
Patient: What does that monitoring involve?
Doctor: We will use median, ulnar, and posterior tibial nerve somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) in a standard fashion. These methods help us monitor the function of your motor pathways during the surgery. Transcranial motor evoked potential (TCMEP) and direct cortical motor evoked potential (DCMEP) will also be used.
Patient: I see. And what about the stimulation?
Doctor: For TCMEP, we will use a multi-pulse train of six with a pulse width of 50 µsec and an interstimulus interval (ISI) of 2 ms (500 Hz). The voltage stimulation will be between 100 and 300 volts, controlling for the inhibition of the "crossover" response. For DCMEP, the stimulation parameters include a multi-pulse train of five delivered at a constant current of 15 mA with a pulse width of 500 µsec and an ISI of 2 ms (500 Hz).
Patient: Okay, that's a lot of information. What about the monitoring sites?
Doctor: We will use upper and lower extremity muscles as target acquisition sites. Standard intraoperative electromyography (EMG) needle electrodes will be used for TCMEP and DCMEP during the surgery.
Patient: Got it. When do you collect the TCMEP data?
Doctor: TCMEP data will be collected before the incision is made. The stimulus will be delivered and optimized to inhibit a "crossover" recording from the ipsilateral hand muscles.
Patient: And what about the electrodes on my scalp?
Doctor: Three sets of stimulation electrodes will be affixed to your scalp using corkscrew needle electrodes. This will provide three channels of motor stimulation to switch between using a TCS 4 constant voltage stimulator unit. This technique allows for better optimization of the TCMEP recordings.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything. I'm ready to proceed with the surgery.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will do our best to ensure your safety and a successful outcome. We'll keep you and your family informed throughout the process.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you presented to the Emergency Department in December 2020 with a large ulcerated and necrotic bulging lesion on your forehead. Can you tell me more about how it started and how it has progressed?
Patient: Yes, it started as a small 2 cm bruise-like patch on my forehead about four months before I came to the hospital. Then it rapidly developed into a large purplish plaque after one month and eventually to the current presentation.
Doctor: I see. Ill-defined, dusky erythematous plaques were also observed extending on the parietal and frontal areas of your scalp and face, along with violaceous-darkish nodules. Are you aware of any comorbidities that you have, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, diabetes, or ischemic encephalopathy?
Patient: Yes, I have all of those conditions.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. During your physical examination, we also found bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Your relatives provided us with photographic documentation of the evolution of your lesion. I understand that the second lockdown in Italy and the fear of SARS-CoV-2 contagion led them to postpone your medical evaluation. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: We performed a biopsy from a violaceous nodule on your lesion, which showed a full dermal proliferation of irregular anastomosing vascular channels lined by single or double layers of enlarged endothelial cells. These cells permeated between collagen bundles, causing "collagen dissection." The endothelial cells were large and pleomorphic, with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. They were immunoreactive for CD31, CD34, and ERG, with no observed HHV8 expression or MYC overexpression.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Based on these data, we have confirmed the diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the scalp. We also conducted a total body computed tomography (CT) scan that showed cervical lymphadenopathy without brain or visceral metastases. 
Patient: So, what's the next step, doctor?
Doctor: While radiotherapy and electrochemotherapy were considered for your treatment, we decided not to perform these due to your advanced age, comorbidities, and the large size of the tumor. Instead, we referred you to palliative care for symptom management and to improve your quality of life.
Patient: I understand. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having this really bad headache for the past three days. The pain is sharp and constant, and I would say it's about an 8 out of 10 in severity.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history? Do you have any pre-existing conditions?
Patient: Yes, I have hyperlipidemia and I usually suffer from one or two migraines per month.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. Have you experienced any other symptoms along with the headache, like nausea or vomiting?
Patient: Yes, actually. I've been feeling nauseous and I've vomited three times.
Doctor: I understand. What medications have you taken recently to try to alleviate the pain?
Patient: I took sumatriptan, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen within the past 48 hours, but they didn't help much.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Let me examine your head. *Examines patient* I noticed some mild bilateral occipital tenderness to palpation, but no neurological deficits or midline tenderness. I recommend we try some additional medications in the ED triage. We'll start with metoclopramide 10 mg and ketorolac 15 mg intravenously. 
Patient: Okay, I hope that helps.
*60 minutes later*
Doctor: How are you feeling now? Has the pain improved after receiving the medications?
Patient: It's a little better, but I still have a lot of head pain. I'd say it's about a 7 out of 10 in severity now.
Doctor: I see. Let's try a different approach. We're going to administer bilateral GON blocks with a total of one mL of 1% lidocaine to each site. 
Patient: Alright, if you think that will help.
*15 minutes after the procedure*
Doctor: How is your pain now, after the GON blocks?
Patient: It's much better, thank you. I'd say it's about a 3 out of 10 now.
Doctor: Great, let's continue to monitor your pain. 
*1.5 hours post-procedure*
Doctor: How are you feeling now? Is the pain still at a 3 out of 10?
Patient: Yes, it's still at a 3. It's definitely an improvement from before.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. I will schedule a follow-up phone interview for nine days after this emergency department visit to check on your progress. 
*During the follow-up phone interview*
Doctor: Hi, how has your pain been since your last emergency department visit?
Patient: My pain resolved over the course of 24 hours, and I haven't had another migraine since then.
Doctor: That's great news! I'm glad to hear that your pain has resolved. If you experience any more severe headaches in the future, don't hesitate to reach out for help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you're a 32-year-old female Cameroonian, gravida 4 para 3, and you're currently at 34 weeks of gestation. Can you tell me what brings you to the labour and delivery unit today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've had a severe generalized headache for about 8 hours now and I'm struggling to speak properly. I also have right-sided paralysis and blurred vision. I haven't had any convulsions, though.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any epigastric pain, difficulty breathing, or had any recent trauma or falls?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those.
Doctor: Okay. Can you tell me a bit about your antenatal care for this pregnancy? When did you start and have you had any issues?
Patient: I started antenatal care at 18 weeks, and my booking blood pressure was 100/70 mmHg. I've done four ANCs and all of them were uneventful. My blood pressure was always less than 140/90 mmHg during those visits.
Doctor: What about proteinuria? Were your urine dipsticks tested during the ANCs?
Patient: Yes, my urine dipsticks were tested during the four ANCs and they were all negative for proteinuria.
Doctor: Have you had any neurological symptoms such as headaches during this pregnancy?
Patient: No, I haven't had any headaches during this pregnancy.
Doctor: Do you have any history of gestational hypertension or any family history of chronic hypertension, diabetes, or chronic kidney diseases?
Patient: I did have gestational hypertension in my third pregnancy, but there's no family history of chronic hypertension, diabetes, or kidney diseases.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Upon examination, you're afebrile with a blood pressure of 182/126 mmHg and a pulse of 112 beats/minute. Your neurological examination revealed a Glasgow coma score of 13/15, right-sided hemiparesis, and expressive Broca's aphasia. There were no signs of meningeal irritation. Your abdomen is distended with a fundal height of 35 cm, and the fetus is in a longitudinal lie with a cephalic presentation. The cervix is long, posterior, soft, and closed with a station of -1. Based on this, our working diagnosis is severe pre-eclampsia complicated by stroke.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What's the next step, Doctor?
Doctor: We performed an emergency obstetric ultrasound, which showed a live fetus with an estimated weight of 2300 g at 33 weeks of gestation. We also did an emergency cerebral non-contrast CT scan that showed a 3.2 cm hyperdense region in the left parietal lobe with surrounding hypodensity due to clot retraction.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there's a clot in your brain causing the stroke symptoms you're experiencing. Our team will proceed with emergency management, which includes administering MgSO4 and monitoring your condition closely.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 27-year-old Chinese Han female. You were accidentally noted to have a low SUA level on two occasions during your routine check-ups in the local hospital. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been feeling fine. I don't have any discomfort or pain.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Have you experienced any joint pain, loin pain, hematuria, urine foam, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, or diarrhea?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Alright. Since you were asymptomatic but had those low SUA levels, you were admitted into the metabolism division at the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University for further investigation. We performed thorough laboratory and imaging examinations. The biochemical tests confirmed the diagnosis of hypouricemia, with your SUA level at 0.33 mg/dl, and hyperuricosuria, with your FEUA at 50%.
Patient: Hmm, what are the normal ranges for those levels?
Doctor: The current reference ranges for SUA used in our laboratory department are 3.5–7.0 mg/dL in males and 2.5–6.0 mg/dL in females. As for FEUA, the reference range is 4–10%, irrespective of gender. So your levels are quite low.
Patient: I see. Were there any other findings?
Doctor: Other biomedical findings were within normal range or negative. We also performed an ultrasound, and no kidney stones were found. We excluded acquired hypouricemia resulting from Fanconi syndrome and other clinical disorders.
Patient: That's a relief. What about my family's medical history?
Doctor: Both of your parents are alive and healthy, with no evident medical history such as urolithiasis and AKI. Your father's SUA concentration is 3.68 mg/dl, which is within the lower-normal range, and your mother's is 4.35 mg/dl, which is within the fully normal range. A FEUA test was not performed for both parents because they refused to have it done. You don't have any siblings, and there is no history of hereditary diseases or specific physical abnormalities in your family.
Patient: Oh, okay. I did mention to the doctor that I'm a vegetarian and don't really eat meat. Does that have anything to do with my condition?
Doctor: It's possible that your diet could contribute to your low SUA levels, but based on the overall information, it's not the sole reason for your hypouricemia and hyperuricosuria.
Patient: Alright. So, what's the next step? Do I need any special treatment?
Doctor: At this moment, no special treatment is recommended. We will continue to monitor your condition and perform regular check-ups to ensure there are no complications. It's important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet, and keep in touch with your healthcare team for any concerns or questions.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the thorough explanation and care. I'll make sure to follow up on my condition and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Doctor: Both of your parents are alive and healthy, with no evident medical history such as urolithiasis and AKI. Your father's SUA concentration is 3.68 mg/dl, which is within the lower-normal range, and your mother's is 4.35 mg/dl, which is within the fully normal range. A FEUA test was not performed for both parents because they refused to have it done. You don't have any siblings, and there is no history of hereditary diseases or specific physical abnormalities in your family.
Patient: Oh, okay. I did mention to the doctor that I'm a vegetarian and don't really eat meat. Does that have anything to do with my condition?
Doctor: It's possible that your diet could contribute to your low SUA levels, but based on the overall information, it's not the sole reason for your hypouricemia and hyperuricosuria.
Patient: Alright. So, what's the next step? Do I need any special treatment?
Doctor: At this moment, no special treatment is recommended. We will continue to monitor your condition and perform regular check-ups to ensure there are no complications. It's important to maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet, and keep in touch with your healthcare team for any concerns or questions.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate the thorough explanation and care. I'll make sure to follow up on my condition and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm the oncologist who will be treating you. We have diagnosed you with locally advanced rectal carcinoma that is infiltrating the dental line and has lymph node metastases. We found this through a computed tomography (CT) scan (Fig. a) and a proctoscopy. You came to us with problems with defecation, constipation, and tumor-related anemia. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I've been having a lot of trouble with those issues lately.
Doctor: I understand that you also experienced painful stenosis, which prevented us from performing an endoscopic ultrasound. Apart from hypothyroidism, do you have any significant preexisting diseases or a history of cancer in close family members?
Patient: No, I don't have any other diseases, and there's no history of cancer in my family.
Doctor: Alright, thank you for the information. It seems that you haven't been exposed to any occupational noxae, and you don't smoke or drink substantial quantities of alcohol, which is good to know. We performed a histological examination of a biopsy specimen of the tumor, and it revealed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a large cell NEC component. We confirmed this by strong diffuse staining for synaptophysin and CD56. The result of chromogranin A testing was negative, and your Ki67 index was greater than 80%.
Patient: Oh, that sounds concerning. What does that mean, exactly?
Doctor: It means that the NEC component has a high grade, specifically grade 3 (G3) NEC of large cell type. We also found more than ten metastases in both lobes of your liver through a CT scan. So, your TNM stage is cT3cN1cM1. 
Patient: That is worrisome. What's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: We will be starting you on a regimen of cisplatin (CDDP; 20 mg/m2 on days 1–5, every 4 weeks) in combination with irinotecan (IRI; 50 mg/m2/day on days 1/8/15, every 4 weeks), which is known for its efficacy in both colorectal cancer and NEC. In parallel, we will also perform conventionally fractionated pelvic radiotherapy up to 50.4 Gy (reference point dose, intensity-modulated radiation therapy) to help alleviate your pain.
Patient: Okay, I understand. I hope this treatment helps me.
Doctor: We will closely monitor your progress and adjust the treatment as needed. It's important to follow the treatment timeline and let us know if you experience any new symptoms or side effects.
Patient: I will, thank you for explaining everything to me. I really appreciate it.
Doctor: You're welcome. I'm here to help you through this journey. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 38-year-old Liberian female and I'm currently 12 weeks pregnant. I came to the emergency department because I've been experiencing low-grade fever, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, worsening abdominal pain, and intermittent spotting for the past 3 weeks.
Doctor: I see. Let's check your vital signs and do a physical exam. *After checking* Your vital signs are stable and your physical exam shows a gravida abdomen, but is otherwise unremarkable. We'll need to do some laboratory examinations to further investigate your symptoms.
Patient: Okay, what kind of tests will you do?
Doctor: We'll start with a blood test to measure your beta hCG levels and perform a pelvic ultrasound. *After tests* Your beta hCG level is 118471 and the ultrasound has confirmed a 12-week viable intrauterine pregnancy. We'll admit you to the hospital for close monitoring.
Patient: Alright, thank you.
Doctor: During your hospital stay, you developed a massive pleural effusion, low-grade fever, progressive worsening abdominal pain, and a spontaneous abortion. We performed a non-contrast-enhanced computed tomography of your chest, which revealed a large right-sided pleural effusion. We also did a contrast-enhanced computed tomography of your abdomen and pelvis, which showed bilateral hilar adenopathy, ascites, thickening and enhancement of the peritoneum, and mottled nodular-appearing soft tissue, which is suspicious for peritoneal carcinomatosis.
Patient: Oh no, what does that mean?
Doctor: We consulted with surgical and oncology specialists for the possibility of exploratory laparotomy and discussed treatment options for presumed ovarian neoplasm. We also did more blood work, which revealed an elevated carbohydrate antigen (CA) 125 and a positive QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. However, your adenosine deaminase, CA 19, alpha-fetoprotein, and inhibin B levels are within normal limits.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: We performed a diagnostic laparoscopy with biopsy, which revealed significant pelvis ascites and diffuse miliary lesions throughout the peritoneum. You then underwent dilatation and curettage. The histopathologic examination showed chronic granulomatous inflammation with no evidence of neoplasm.
Patient: What does that mean for me?
Doctor: Special stains on the tissue sections and ascitic fluid stain revealed rare acid-fast bacilli, which suggests mycobacterial granulomatous peritonitis. Upon further questioning, you indicated that you had a positive PPD skin test a year ago but didn't receive any follow-up treatment. We have started you on a four-drug anti-tuberculous therapy.
Patient: Will that help me recover?
Doctor: Yes, with the appropriate treatment, you should have a complete recovery. It's important to follow up with your healthcare team and complete the full course of the therapy.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'll make sure to follow your advice.

A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 31-year-old female patient with symptomatic postpartum deep venous thrombosis in your right leg. Can you describe the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, my right leg has been really swollen and painful. It's been difficult to walk around.
Doctor: I understand. So, before your surgical thrombectomy, you received a suprarenal IVC filter due to the short distance between the thrombus in the distal IVC and the inflow of renal veins. The surgical access was established via venotomy of the common femoral vein, and an occlusion balloon was used for the thrombectomy. How did you feel after the procedure?
Patient: I felt a bit better, but still had some pain and swelling in my leg.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. In a follow-up CT, we found that the filter had dislodged and tilted towards the right IVC wall with its legs piercing the contralateral wall and extending into the left renal vein. This was likely due to the surgical thrombectomy. You were given oral anticoagulation with Warfarin, but unfortunately, there was a re-thrombosis. We then performed catheter-directed thrombolysis, including stenting of the common iliac veins and the IVC. However, we didn't attempt filter retrieval at that time due to the large amount of clot within the filter.
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened next?
Doctor: After 5 weeks of Warfarin therapy, you were scheduled for a retrieval, which was considered mandatory due to the displaced and tilted filter with penetrating legs. We introduced a 14-F sheath, an SOS catheter, a Bentson wire, and an EN Snare to create a loop. We attempted the single loop-snare technique several times, but it kept slipping around the filter legs.
Patient: That sounds difficult. What did you do then?
Doctor: To stabilize the loop, we formed a second loop using the same technique around the filter tip. With two loops around the filter tip, we were finally able to successfully pull the filter away from the wall and into the 14F sheath.
Patient: That's a relief! What's the next step now?
Doctor: A follow-up venography will be performed to ensure that the filter has been successfully removed and to monitor your condition. You'll need to continue taking your anticoagulation medication and follow up with us regularly to prevent any future complications.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me. I'll make sure to follow your instructions and keep you updated on my progress.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and don't hesitate to contact us if you have any concerns or questions.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, what brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been coughing up blood for the past three days, and I'm really worried.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Have you experienced any similar symptoms in the past?
Patient: Yeah, I had massive haemoptysis last year, but they couldn't identify any disorder during my follow-up examination.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any significant past medical history we should be aware of?
Patient: Yes, I have hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, and atrioventricular block. I also have an implanted dual chamber pacemaker. Oh, and I don't have a history of smoking.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. Let's start with a physical examination. We'll check your vitals and listen to your lungs.
[After examination]
Doctor: Your blood pressure is 146/72 mmHg, pulse is 86 beats/min, temperature is 36.6 °C, respiratory rate is 20/min, and your blood oxygen saturation level is 95% on room air. Your physical examination seems unremarkable, without any coarse crackles on the right lung field. We'll also need to perform some laboratory tests to check if everything is within normal limits.
[After receiving laboratory test results]
Doctor: Your laboratory test results are within normal limits. We'll need to take a chest radiograph to further investigate the issue.
[After reviewing the chest radiograph]
Doctor: Your chest radiograph shows a homogenous, flat opacity along the right heart border in the lower lung field (Fig. A). We'll perform a chest computed tomography (CT) scan to get a better understanding of your condition.
[After reviewing the chest CT scan]
Doctor: The chest CT scan demonstrated a consolidation due to a collapsed right lower lobe and a diaphragmatic hernia (Fig. B). Interestingly, a chest CT performed five years ago showed an expanded bronchus in the small right lower lobe, suggesting pulmonary hypoplasia of the right inferior lobe (Fig. C). Let's move forward with a dynamic CT angiography to check for any blood leakage.
[After reviewing the dynamic CT angiography]
Doctor: We couldn't detect any extravasation of blood on the arterial and venous phase in the angiography. However, a bronchoscopic examination revealed that your right inferior lobar bronchus was filled with blood clots (Fig. D).
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is concerning. We performed a bronchial artery angiography, which confirmed the expansion and meandering of the bronchial arteries and the growth of the reticular artery from the diaphragm arteries (Fig. E). We attempted two arterial embolizations and also plugged an endobronchial Watanabe spigot into your right inferior lobar bronchus, but unfortunately, they failed to stop the haemoptysis.
Patient: What's the next step then?
Doctor: We had to perform a thoracoscopic right lower lobectomy to remove the affected area. The excised surgical specimen presented a small hypoaerated, atrophied, and occluded right inferior lobe. The bronchus was underdeveloped and irregular throughout its running (Fig. F).
Patient: I see. What should I do now, Doctor?
Doctor: It's important to monitor your condition closely and follow up with us regularly. We'll keep an eye on any changes and manage your symptoms as needed. We're here to support you through this process.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 62-year-old, right-handed male carrier. Have you been experiencing any tremor or ataxia recently?
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any tremors or problems with balance.
Doctor: Good to know. We just took your vitals during the examination. Your blood pressure is 125/88 mmHg, and your heart rate is 88 bpm. Are you currently taking any medications for your blood pressure?
Patient: Yes, I'm taking irbesartan and hydrochlorothiazide to control it.
Doctor: Great, it seems that those medications are helping. Your BMI is 26.9, which is slightly above the normal range. Now, we did some tests during the examination, such as finger-to-nose touching and tandem walk. You showed no difficulty in performing these tasks.
Patient: Yes, I didn't have any problems with those tests.
Doctor: We also noticed a slight increased tone in your right and left extremities, but your movements were symmetrical. Your deep tendon reflexes were normal, scoring a 2+ in all four extremities.
Patient: Hmm, that's good to know.
Doctor: Additionally, your vibration sense, tactile sensation, and cold sensation were all normal. We didn't find any cognitive abnormalities during the neuropsychological examination, and you haven't reported any psychiatric symptoms, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I haven't experienced any issues in those areas.
Doctor: That's great. We also conducted an MRI, which revealed the MCP sign. There were some additional white matter changes detected in the splenium of the corpus callosum.
Patient: Oh, what does that mean?
Doctor: It could be related to some underlying neurological condition. We'll need to keep an eye on it and possibly conduct further tests to determine the exact cause.
Patient: Okay, I understand. Just let me know what I need to do for the follow-up.
Doctor: Absolutely, we will keep you informed and guide you through any necessary follow-up appointments or tests. In the meantime, continue taking your blood pressure medications and try to maintain a healthy lifestyle.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to us. Take care!

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]
