Follow-up Exercise 1:
Explain the significance of the MCP sign in the context of the patient's symptoms and the MRI findings.

Solution to Follow-up Exercise 1:
The MCP sign refers to the presence of a positive reflex in the middle finger when the patient's elbow is flexed. In this case, the patient showed a positive MCP sign, which is considered abnormal. This finding suggests a possible neurological abnormality in the patient's upper motor neurons. The MRI findings, including the white matter changes in the splenium of the corpus callosum, further support the presence of an underlying neurological condition. The splenium of the corpus callosum is a region of the brain that connects the left and right hemispheres. The white matter changes detected in this area may indicate damage or disruption to the communication between the two hemispheres, which can affect various neurological functions.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, young lady. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been having this problem with my neck swelling up on the left side since I was 6 years old.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any treatment for this swelling?
Patient: Yes, I had some treatment to control the inflammation.
Doctor: Good. Did you have any tests done after the inflammation was controlled?
Patient: Yes, I had a barium esophagography done.
Doctor: Alright. And what did the results show?
Patient: The results showed a PSF on the left side of my neck.
Doctor: Okay, and did you have a CT scan as well?
Patient: Yes, and it showed an air- and barium-containing fistula.
Doctor: I understand. We decided to perform a MLS as the first-line treatment for you. Do you remember the details of the procedure?
Patient: Hmm, I remember the doctor saying that the fistula was narrow and the tissue wasn't fragile.
Doctor: That's correct. We made the incision as small as possible during the surgery (Fig. , ). The operation was completed uneventfully (Fig. ). On the fifth postoperative day, we performed another barium esophagography. Did you experience any leakage after that?
Patient: No, there wasn't any leakage.
Doctor: Great. You were able to start free oral intake on the same day, right?
Patient: Yes, I was able to eat and drink without any problems.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. You had an uneventful recovery and were discharged from the hospital 7 days after the surgery. How have you been feeling since then?
Patient: I've been feeling much better, and I haven't had any recurrence of the swelling.
Doctor: That's excellent news. I'm happy to hear that you're doing well. Remember to come back for regular check-ups to ensure everything remains fine. If you ever experience any issues, don't hesitate to contact us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you are here for an evaluation of your ascites and treatment of AN-BP. Can you please tell me about your history with self-induced vomiting and laxative abuse?
Patient: Yes, I've been dealing with self-induced vomiting and laxative abuse for 20 years now. I've been taking more than 200 tablets per day.
Doctor: That's quite severe. Have you received any previous treatments for this issue?
Patient: Yes, I've had supportive psychotherapy and symptomatic treatment from psychiatrists, including being hospitalized 13 times.
Doctor: I see. During the physical examination, we noticed some epigastric vein dilatation and striae cutis distensae on your swelling abdomen, which was filled with ascites. We also conducted some blood tests. The results indicated hypoalbuminemia, increased hepatic and biliary enzyme levels, an increased creatinine level, hypokalemia, and anemia. Have you experienced any symptoms related to these findings?
Patient: Yeah, I've been feeling really tired and weak lately.
Doctor: That could be due to the anemia. We also performed an abdominal ultrasonogram, which showed findings of chronic hepatitis, such as an irregular liver surface, a dull margin, and heterogeneity of the parenchyma. A computed tomography scan revealed a gastro-renal shunt, but no varices were detected. We suspected portal hypertension due to liver cirrhosis, so we performed a liver biopsy.
Patient: What did the liver biopsy show?
Doctor: The biopsy showed only slight pericellular fibrosis without evidence of liver cirrhosis. However, liver fibrosis was proven by the increase in liver fibrosis markers, such as type IV collagen 7S (8.5 ng/mL) and hyaluronic acid (400 ng/mL). We also conducted psychological testing, which showed remarkable depression and anxiety.
Patient: What's the plan for my treatment?
Doctor: During your inpatient care, we provided nutritional treatment and diuretic drugs to control the ascites. After your general state improved, we initiated an inpatient cognitive behavioral treatment. You were discharged 2 months after admission because your ascites almost disappeared and your body weight increased by approximately 3 kg.
Patient: But did my blood test results improve?
Doctor: Unfortunately, serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (γ-GTP), and creatinine were not significantly improved.
Patient: What can I do now?
Doctor: During our 3-month follow-up, we found that your ascites were well controlled with diuretic drugs. We would like you to limit your daily activities to prevent any complications. As for the aforementioned serum levels, no significant changes were observed, but we will continue monitoring them closely.
Patient: Okay, I'll try to limit my activities. Thank you, doctor.

A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 55-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of breast cancer. What brings you in today?
Patient: I recently had a surveillance computed tomography (CT) scan of my chest, abdomen, and pelvis, and they found something.
Doctor: Yes, I see here that the CT scan showed incidental acute appendicitis. Were you experiencing any symptoms when you came in for the scan?
Patient: No, I was asymptomatic during the scan, but in the following days, I developed nausea and vomiting along with right lower quadrant abdominal pain.
Doctor: That's consistent with appendicitis. We'll have to admit you to the general surgery service for treatment. I also noticed from your chart that you have an extensive history with cancer, is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, it all started in 2014 when I had a resection of an enlarging, ulcerating chest mass on the right side.
Doctor: I see that the pathology report from the wide local excision of the mass demonstrated estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, and HER2/neu-negative metastatic adenocarcinoma. At the time, the primary source of the cancer was unknown. You underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy, both of which were normal, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. My oncology team has been closely monitoring me, and I've been treated with tamoxifen for hormone therapy.
Doctor: I also noticed that in May of 2017, due to an enlarged anterior mediastinal wall lymph node discovered on CT surveillance, you underwent a CT-guided biopsy and positron emission tomography (PET). The biopsy was negative for malignancy, but the PET showed abnormal hypermetabolic activity within a retrosternal nodule, intense activity in a mixed focus in the manubrium, and several hypermetabolic nodes within the mediastinum. It also showed an abnormal hypermetabolic focus in the cecum, which was suspicious for a colon primary. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, they tried to do a colonoscopy, but the gastroenterologist couldn't advance the colonoscope past the transverse colon due to technical reasons.
Doctor: I see. Medical oncology decided to continue with close surveillance. In January 2018, you developed right axillary lymphadenopathy, and an ultrasound-guided biopsy was performed. What were the results of that biopsy?
Patient: I don't remember exactly, can you please check my records?
Doctor: Yes, let me take a look. It appears that the biopsy revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma with the same hormone receptor profile as your original breast cancer. Your oncology team will need to adjust your treatment plan accordingly. In the meantime, we need to focus on treating your appendicitis. After your surgery, make sure to follow up with your oncologist for further evaluation and management of your cancer.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've come to our services for exertional dyspnoea. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having trouble breathing when I exert myself.
Doctor: I understand. I see from your medical history that you had aortic valve stenosis and received an orthotopic heart transplantation in 1994 for idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy. Unfortunately, we don't have the data from your transplant procedure as it was done 23 years ago. Have you experienced any issues since then?
Patient: No, not really. I've been mostly asymptomatic except for paroxysmal atrial flutter. I got a single chamber pacemaker in 2008 and then had an atrial flutter ablation in 2010.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Have you been adhering to your medication regimen?
Patient: Yep, I've been taking my meds as prescribed.
Doctor: Great. It seems that you haven't shown any signs of transplant rejection on several cardiac biopsies. However, you do have some post-transplant cardiovascular risk factors like systemic hypertension, dyslipidaemia, and stable stage 4 chronic renal dysfunction with an eGFR of 23 mL/min/1.73 m2. We've been monitoring your condition with serial transthoracic echocardiography at our institution, and it has shown progressive degenerative aortic valve disease. 
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: At your presentation, the transthoracic echocardiography showed degenerative bicuspid aortic valve with fusion of the right and left coronary cusps. The appearance of the valve is consistent with severe aortic stenosis, which was confirmed by hemodynamic Doppler assessment. It revealed a peak gradient of 65 mm Hg, an aortic valve area of 0.9 cm2 derived from the continuity equation, and a dimensionless velocity index of 0.24. Your left ventricular function is normal with an ejection fraction of 59% by Simpson's method.
Patient: So, what does all that mean, doc?
Doctor: We performed further evaluation using multi-detector computed tomography (MDCT) to assess your aortic valve and aorto-iliac anatomy. It confirmed the morphology of a heavily calcific bicuspid aortic valve and the absence of associated aortopathy. It also showed that you're suitable for a transfemoral approach. The maximal aortic annulus dimension was measured as 25 mm with an aortic root diameter of 32 mm at the level of the sinuses of Valsalva.
Patient: Okay, and what about my coronary arteries?
Doctor: We performed coronary angiography to screen for cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV) and did not find any evidence of obstructive coronary disease.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: One more thing, upon admission, we noted that you were bradycardic with episodes. We will continue to monitor your condition and discuss the best treatment options for your case.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to us. We're here to help you.

Patient: So, what does all that mean, doc?
Doctor: We performed further evaluation using multi-detector computed tomography (MDCT) to assess your aortic valve and aorto-iliac anatomy. It confirmed the morphology of a heavily calcific bicuspid aortic valve and the absence of associated aortopathy. It also showed that you're suitable for a transfemoral approach. The maximal aortic annulus dimension was measured as 25 mm with an aortic root diameter of 32 mm at the level of the sinuses of Valsalva.
Patient: Okay, and what about my coronary arteries?
Doctor: We performed coronary angiography to screen for cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV) and did not find any evidence of obstructive coronary disease.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: One more thing, upon admission, we noted that you were bradycardic with episodes. We will continue to monitor your condition and discuss the best treatment options for your case.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to reach out to us. We're here to help you.

Patient presents with exertional dyspnoea.
Patient has a history of aortic valve stenosis and orthotopic heart transplantation in 1994 for idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.
Patient has been asymptomatic except for paroxysmal atrial flutter.
Patient has been taking medication as prescribed.
Patient has post-transplant cardiovascular risk factors.
Patient has been monitored with serial transthoracic echocardiography.
Patient has progressive degenerative aortic valve disease.
Patient has degenerative bicuspid aortic valve with fusion of the right and left coronary cusps.
Patient has severe aortic stenosis confirmed by hemodynamic Doppler assessment.
Patient has normal left ventricular function.
Patient has been evaluated with multi-detector computed tomography (MDCT).
Patient is suitable for a transfemoral approach.
Patient has a heavily calcific bicuspid aortic valve and no associated aortopathy.
Patient has normal aortic root diameter.
Patient has normal coronary arteries.
Patient is bradycardic with episodes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I am a 75-year-old woman, and I've been having a loss of appetite for a week now. I'm 132 cm tall and weigh 34 kg.
Doctor: I see. Are you taking any medications currently?
Patient: Yes, I take aspirin, celecoxib, and amlodipine for angina and hypertension.
Doctor: Alright. I will need to run some laboratory examinations to better understand your condition. 
*After the examinations*
Doctor: Your lab results show that your Hb has decreased modestly to 10.7 g/dl. I would like to monitor your condition and ask that you return in two weeks for a follow-up.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
*Two weeks later*
Patient: Doctor, my anorexia has worsened day by day, and I decided to admit myself to the hospital.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. On admission day 1, you were alert and fully oriented. Your blood pressure and pulse rate were stable. However, your laboratory examinations showed that your Hb and hematocrit levels decreased remarkably to 4.8 g/dl and 15%, respectively. Your white blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP) increased slightly to 9900 /mm3 and 4.64 mg/dl, respectively. Additionally, your albumin level decreased to 2.5 g/dl and your creatine level increased slightly to 1.14 mg/dl, with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 41.7 ml/min. We also conducted chest and abdominal computed tomography (CT), but it didn't detect any abnormal lesions.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: On admission day 2, you vomited large amounts of bright red blood, and your Hb level further decreased to 2.9 g/dl. We performed an urgent transfusion of 560 ml of red blood cells. An endoscopic examination detected active bleeding from a gastric ulcer, so we performed endoscopic clipping on the bleeding lesion.
Patient: I'm glad you found the issue. Did my Hb levels improve after that?
Doctor: Yes, your Hb improved to 8.9 g/dl. However, you did not respond to verbal or pain stimuli despite your eyes having opened. You showed normal light reflexes without anisocoria. We performed a brain MRI, including fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) and DWI, which showed high signal intensities in the bilateral cerebellar hemispheres, bilateral watershed regions, right thalamus, and white and gray matter of the bilateral occipital and occipitoparietal lobes. ADC maps show low signal intensities in the cortical and subcortical regions with small high signal intensities in the surrounding.
Patient: That sounds concerning. What does it mean, and what should I do now?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide appropriate treatment. It's essential to follow up with us regularly to track your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan. Please let us know if you experience any new or worsening symptoms.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and will follow your advice.
generated_soap:
S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you tell me why you were admitted to the hospital back in June 2016?
Patient: Yeah, I was admitted because of weakness in my right arm and problems with my speech, like slurring.
Doctor: I see. You were diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the left middle cerebral artery area and deep vein thrombosis. Your ECG demonstrated normal sinus rhythm and echocardiography revealed no intra-cardiac thrombus or vegetation. You were then discharged with a prescription for apixaban. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: In August 2016, you were readmitted to the hospital due to recurrent right arm weakness and slurred speech. The MRI showed multiple cerebral infarctions in both cerebral hemispheres and the cerebellum. At this point, Trousseau's syndrome was suspected. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: So, your apixaban was stopped and you were given an intravenous drip of heparin instead. Echocardiography revealed mild mitral regurgitation with vegetation on the mitral valve. Although your lab results showed no evidence of infection, you were given ceftriaxone and gentamicin as a precaution against infective endocarditis. You were then referred to our hospital for surgery. 
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: A CT scan revealed a left renal infarction and multiple swollen lymph nodes around both the abdominal aorta and stomach with antral hypertrophy. This suggested advanced gastric cancer or lymphoma. Despite the heparin and antibiotics therapy, the vegetation on your mitral valve didn't change. So, cardiac surgery was performed on day 5 after your referral. 
Patient: Okay, and what happened during the surgery?
Doctor: During the surgery, extracorporeal circulation was instituted employing aortic and bicaval cannulation. After aortic cross-clamping, the mitral valve was exposed via a left atriotomy. Both mitral leaflets had vegetation on the surface, and a major vegetation 15 mm in width was evident on the anterior leaflet. These were resected in their entirety and replaced with a 25-mm Epic bioprosthesis.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: Continuous intravenous heparin administration was resumed the following day, aiming for an activated partial thromboplastin time of between 40 and 50 seconds. Histologic analysis revealed that the vegetations were actually thrombi covered with vascular endothelium and that your mitral leaflet tissue was not damaged. Based on these findings, you were diagnosed with NB.
Patient: So, what's the next step for me?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition and adjust your medications as needed. It's important that you attend all follow-up appointments and report any new or worsening symptoms to your healthcare team.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything to me.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I heard you've been experiencing some wrist pain and unsightly appearance of your wrist after a previous fracture. Can you please describe how it feels and when these symptoms started to develop?
Patient: Yeah, the pain is mostly on the ulnar side of my wrist, and it started about a year after the fracture. The appearance of my wrist seems a bit deformed too.
Doctor: I see. Based on the physical examination and the tests we ran, it appears that you have a growth plate fracture in your right distal radius, specifically a Salter–Harris type II fracture. You were initially treated with cast immobilization and closed reduction, which allowed the fracture to heal. However, the wrist pain and deformity you're experiencing now are due to a condition called partial physeal arrest.
Patient: Oh, I see. What does that mean?
Doctor: Partial physeal arrest occurs when the growth plate in your wrist is damaged, causing it to stop growing properly. In your case, radiographs showed a shortening deformity of the distal radius and an abnormal radial inclination of the articular surface. A CT scan was also performed to evaluate the deformity and for preoperative simulation with a low-radiation setting.
Patient: So, what's the plan to fix this?
Doctor: We have planned a two-stage operation for you. The first stage will involve a procedure called distraction osteogenesis to gradually lengthen the affected bone. The second stage will be the Langenskiöld procedure, which aims to remove the physeal bar and reestablish physeal growth.
Patient: Will this help with the pain and appearance of my wrist?
Doctor: Yes, the goal of the operation is to correct the deformities of the wrist and improve its appearance and function. In the first operation, we'll use a closed-wedge osteotomy to correct the distal radius, and an external fixator called the Orthofix MiniRail Fixator™ will be used for lengthening.
Patient: Okay, that sounds good. What do I need to do to prepare for the surgery?
Doctor: We have obtained informed consent from your guardians to report the procedure and proceed with the operation. All procedures have been approved by the Ethics Committee of our institution, and we will adhere to all of the recommended guidelines for an experimental investigation involving human subjects.
Patient: Got it. Thank you for explaining everything to me. I'm looking forward to getting this fixed.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We'll be here to support you throughout the process.

The closed-wedge osteotomy is performed in the first stage of the operation to correct the distal radius deformity. It involves making a wedge-shaped incision in the bone and removing a portion of the bone to realign the affected area. This allows for gradual lengthening of the bone and correction of the deformity. The closed-wedge osteotomy is a common technique used in orthopedic surgeries to correct bone deformities and restore proper alignment.

Follow-up Exercise 2:
What is the purpose of the external fixator, specifically the Orthofix MiniRail Fixator™, in the first stage of the operation?

Solution:
The external fixator, specifically the Orthofix MiniRail Fixator™, is used in the first stage of the operation to provide support and stability to the fractured bone. It consists of a series of metal rods that are attached to the bone through small incisions. The external fixator allows for controlled movement of the bone during the healing process, promoting proper alignment and gradual lengthening. It also helps to distribute the forces across the bone, reducing the risk of further complications.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues lately. I work at a shrimp farm in Yingkou, and I had watery diarrhea on August 24th.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and any relevant history?
Patient: Well, I had a single episode of watery diarrhea, dizziness, and vomiting after consuming raw mollusc from the sediment in Yingkou. I don't have any immune-compromising diseases, and I don't abuse alcohol.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. How did you manage your symptoms after the episode?
Patient: I took ciprofloxacin for two days, and the watery diarrhea disappeared after three days of antibiotic treatment.
Doctor: Okay, it seems that the antibiotic helped. Did you have any laboratory tests done?
Patient: Yes, I had some biochemical tests and my white blood cell count was high, 14 × 109/L. They also did a stool culture.
Doctor: Were there any findings from the stool culture?
Patient: The stool culture was spread onto Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose and MacConkey agar plates, and it showed suspected positive results for V. cholerae.
Doctor: I see. Were there any further tests done to confirm the presence of V. cholerae?
Patient: Yes, they obtained a pure culture and identified the bacterium as V. cholerae through the VITEK-2 bacterial identifier system and sequencing of the 16S rDNA genes.
Doctor: Did they perform any tests to determine the specific strain of V. cholerae?
Patient: They did an agglutination test with O1 and O139 antisera, and it showed that the strain was a non-O1/O139 V. cholerae.
Doctor: Alright. Were there any tests conducted to assess the virulence factors of the V. cholerae strain?
Patient: Yes, they did a PCR test for outer membrane protein, TCP expression, haemagglutinin, protease, and central regulatory protein, among others.
Doctor: What were the results of the PCR tests?
Patient: The results showed that the strain was only positive for the outer membrane protein, TCP expression, haemagglutinin, protease, and central regulatory protein.
Doctor: Thank you for providing all this information. It seems that you have been infected with a non-O1/O139 V. cholerae strain, which can cause mild watery diarrhea. It's good to know that your symptoms have resolved after the antibiotic treatment. Please continue monitoring your health and follow up with your healthcare provider if necessary. And remember to practice good hygiene and food safety to prevent future infections.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I'll keep that in mind and take better care of myself.

A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]

Patient: Oh, I don't have any remarkable medical history. I've been pretty healthy overall.
Doctor: I understand you were admitted to another hospital due to fever, fatigue, and anorexia. What treatments were provided there?
Patient: They gave me acetaminophen and antibiotics, but my condition kept getting worse. I even started having vomiting and myalgia, which made it hard to move.
Doctor: I see, so you were transferred to our hospital 7 days after your initial admission. Upon admission, we found that your liver enzyme and creatine phosphokinase levels were high. Have you ever experienced jaundice, pruritus, clay stools, melena, hematemesis, abdominal distension, or altered sensorium?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those issues.
Doctor: What about your lifestyle habits? Have you consumed alcohol or experienced any toxic exposure?
Patient: I've only had a small amount of ethanol occasionally, and I haven't been exposed to any toxins that I'm aware of.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. Have you ever had any major surgeries, blood transfusions, or intravenously injected drug use prior to the onset of the disease?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Do you have a history of any chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, tuberculosis, thyroid disease, or blood disorders?
Patient: No, I don't have any of those conditions.
Doctor: Okay, let's discuss your current condition. Upon admission, your vital signs were as follows: body temperature, 37.2 °C; blood pressure, 110/72 mmHg; pulse, 75 beats/min; respiratory rate, 20 breaths/min; and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Our physical examination showed mild enlargement of your liver, no pitting edema in both legs, and no coarse crackles over the lung fields. The laboratory findings are presented in the table, which we'll discuss shortly.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Additionally, a chest radiography showed absence of pulmonary congestion, pleural effusion, and cardiomegaly. Electrocardiography was not performed on admission. Computed tomography of the chest and abdomen revealed minimal pericardial effusion, diffuse swelling, and an internal heterogeneous image in the liver.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: These findings are compatible with acute hepatitis. Although we didn't examine your cardiac function, the other results indicate that you are experiencing acute hepatitis, which might be the cause of your symptoms.
Patient: Oh, I see. What should we do now?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition and provide appropriate treatment to manage your symptoms and the underlying cause of the hepatitis. It's important that you follow our recommendations and attend any follow-up appointments to ensure your recovery.
Patient: Yes, of course. Thank you, doctor.

Follow-up exercises:
1. What is the difference between a subjective finding and an objective finding in a SOAP note?
Solution: A subjective finding is information that is provided by the patient, such as their complaints and history. An objective finding is information that is gathered through physical examination or laboratory tests, such as vital signs or laboratory results.

2. Why is it important to include a differential diagnosis in a SOAP note?
Solution: A differential diagnosis is a list of possible diagnoses that could explain a patient's symptoms. Including a differential diagnosis in a SOAP note helps to ensure that all possible causes are considered and that appropriate treatment is provided.

3. What is the purpose of a follow-up appointment in a SOAP note?
Solution: A follow-up appointment is scheduled to monitor a patient's progress and ensure that they are recovering from their illness or injury. It is also an opportunity to adjust treatment plans as needed

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I was diagnosed with left temporal glial neoplasia in May 2014 after I had a seizure.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms and the tests you had done?
Patient: Well, I had an MRI which showed an infiltrative lesion with poorly defined contours in my left temporal lobe. It also showed an increase in the left temporal gyrus cortex.
Doctor: Hmm, it seems like the lesion compromised a large part of your temporal lobe and extended to the temporal isthmus, the posterior aspect of the insula, and was deep in the trigeminal effigy of the left lateral ventricle. There was also diffuse erasure of the regional cortical sulci and the Sylvian fissure, with slight compression over the atrium of the left lateral ventricle. Did you have a biopsy done to confirm the diagnosis?
Patient: Yes, I had a stereotactic biopsy in April 2014, and it indicated oligodendroglioma grade II.
Doctor: Okay, and how has your treatment been going since then?
Patient: I received TMZ with cycles every 23 days from September 2014 to July 2015. But in 2016, there was tumor growth, so I had an MRI in February.
Doctor: What did the MRI show about the evolution of the tumor?
Patient: The MRI showed an increase in the dimensions of the remaining lesion, especially in the temporal isthmus, which had a similar expansive effect on the adjacent encephalic structures.
Doctor: I understand. And what was the next step in your treatment?
Patient: I underwent a partial surgical resection followed by chemoradiation and lasting 6 cycles of PCV associated with CBD. The CBD dosage ranged from 100 to 200 mg/day.
Doctor: How was your overall health and well-being during the chemoradiation?
Patient: I had an excellent clinical performance, practiced sports, and only had a few symptoms of fatigue and nausea.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Did you have an MRI control after the chemoradiation to assess the results?
Patient: Yes, the MRI control was used to characterize post-operative changes and showed a significant reduction of the infiltrative components of the tumor.
Doctor: That's promising. What was the result of the pathological study after your surgeries?
Patient: After the first surgery, I was still diagnosed with oligodendroglioma grade II. But after the second surgery, I was diagnosed with oligodendroglioma grade III due to an increase in Ki67 staining of 9%.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing all of this information. Based on your current situation, we can discuss the next steps in your treatment plan and continue to monitor your progress closely. It's important to keep an open line of communication and report any new symptoms or concerns you may have.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you were referred to our department in June 2011 by a head and neck surgeon to improve your upper denture retention and stability. Can you tell me a bit about your medical history?
Patient: Sure, doc. I was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary gingiva in May 2005. I had to undergo a bunch of surgeries like extended left maxillectomy, anterior and middle cranial base resection, left ophthalmectomy, and flap reconstruction using the rectus abdominis muscle.
Doctor: I see. During your physical examination, I noticed a recessed deformation on the left side of your face due to the left ophthalmectomy. The function of your left levator palpebrae muscle has been eliminated to a slight elevation using the frontal muscle. There's also a metal plate anchored to the inferior wall of your orbit. How have you been managing with these changes?
Patient: It's been tough, but I'm getting used to it.
Doctor: I also observed that during the mesh titanium plate reconstruction, your left ethmoid bone, inferior nasal turbinate, maxilla, alisphenoid, medial and lateral pterygoid muscle were excised. Intraorally, your left maxilla has been excised from the midline and the rectus abdominis muscle flap was sutured directly to your soft palate. The peripheral mucous membrane around your left upper lip is scarred, without the oral vestibule. Have you experienced any discomfort or difficulty with this?
Patient: Yes, sometimes it's uncomfortable and the flap margin has moved along with the surrounding soft tissue.
Doctor: I see that the 70 × 50 mm flap is sagging from its weight and is in contact with your mandibular molars, which reduces the volume of your oral cavity unless you wear dentures. Your maxilla has been removed from the midline to the maxillary tuberosity, while your mandible has been removed from the anterior border of the ramus to the coronoid process. Has this caused any issues with your dentures?
Patient: Yeah, it's been a bit difficult to adjust to them.
Doctor: During the reconstruction, the dead space was eliminated by placing the abdominal rectus muscle from the anterior cranial base to the oral cavity (Fig.). Have you noticed any expiratory leakage or food reflux?
Patient: No, I haven't experienced any leakage or food reflux.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Prior to performing surgery, there was no tumor recurrence or metastasis detected. Have you been keeping up with your follow-up appointments to monitor your condition?
Patient: Yes, I have been attending all my follow-up appointments.
Doctor: Great. I also see that you have a mouth opening of 43 mm. Are you experiencing any difficulties with this mouth opening size?
Patient: Not really, I can manage with it.
Doctor: Alright. Based on our conversation and my examination, we will work on improving your denture retention and stability. We may need to make adjustments to your current dentures or consider other options to ensure your comfort and proper function. Please continue to attend your follow-up appointments so we can monitor your condition closely.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello there, I see you've brought your 7-year-old son in today. What seems to be the problem?
Parent: Hi, Doctor. We're from Miandoab. He suddenly started experiencing febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures and was hospitalized in Shahid Abbasi teaching Hospital.
Doctor: I see. Has he had any history of prenatal or postnatal diseases?
Parent: No, he has had a normal growth and just completed the first grade of primary school. His mother and I are cousins, but we are both healthy.
Doctor: Okay. So, after controlling his seizures with bolus doses of phenobarbital and phenytoin, did his condition improve?
Parent: Unfortunately, his consciousness level decreased, and he needed endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. Then he was transferred to the tertiary subspecialty ward in Urmia’s Motahari Hospital.
Doctor: I understand. When I first examined him, he was in a deep coma, but his vital signs were normal. Upon further physical examination, I noticed his pupils were dilated with an inadequate response to light, his liver was palpable about 4 cm below the costal margin, his muscular tone was severely diminished, and deep tendon reflexes were undetectable. His examination was otherwise normal.
Parent: What do the laboratory tests say about his condition?
Doctor: The routine laboratory tests revealed a nonketotic hypoglycemia and elevated liver enzymes. We consulted with an endocrinologist and took blood and urine samples for further evaluation into the exact cause of his hypoglycemia.
Parent: What did those tests reveal?
Doctor: The tests ruled out several possible causes including lipid malabsorption (TG=92 mg/dl, cholesterol 73 mg/dl, LDL=37 mg/dl), disorders of the respiratory chain (lactate=13 ng/dl), adrenal insufficiency (cortisol=62.4µg/dl), hypopituitarism (ACTH=411 pg/ml), and hyper insulinemia (insulin=0.7µIU/ml).
Parent: Did you find any viral or immune cause for his hepatitis?
Doctor: Our pediatric gastroenterologist suggested additional laboratory tests to detect any viral or immune cause of hepatitis, but unfortunately, those tests revealed nothing. The urine toxicology screening test was also negative.
Parent: What should we do now, Doctor?
Doctor: We will continue to closely monitor your son's condition and provide the necessary care. We will also consult with other specialists and perform any additional tests if needed. We'll do our best to find the cause of his condition and provide appropriate treatment.

Positive Impact:
The use of SOAP notes in the medical field has greatly improved the communication and documentation of patient information between healthcare professionals. This standardized format ensures that all necessary information is included and easily understood by all parties involved in the patient's care. It also allows for efficient and accurate transfer of information when patients are transferred between different

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about the injuries you sustained?
Patient: Hi, I had an electrical burn from a power line. It was pretty bad.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. It looks like you had 32% total body surface area third-degree injuries. Can you tell me more about the injury to your left knee?
Patient: Yeah, my left knee got an open joint injury. It was treated with three skin grafting procedures before something else was placed.
Doctor: That's right. The SEF, or spatial external fixator, was placed 24 days after your injury to help stabilize your knee. It was kept on for 8.5 weeks. We used Shantz pins and bars as the external fixator, and it was locked in full extension. 
Patient: Oh, I see. So, what happened after the SEF was placed?
Doctor: After the SEF placement, you required two additional skin grafting procedures on your left knee. You also had a bony prominence resection while in SEF. This means we removed a protruding piece of bone to help with your recovery.
Patient: I didn't know that. Were there any complications during my treatment?
Doctor: No significant complications were recorded during your treatment, which is good news. However, I noticed that there were no PT/OT notes or follow-up recorded. 
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: PT/OT refers to physical therapy and occupational therapy. It's important to have these sessions and follow-ups to ensure proper recovery and regain function in your injured knee. 
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what should I do now?
Doctor: I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess your current condition and create a plan for your ongoing recovery.
Patient: Alright, I'll do that. Thanks for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and wishing you a speedy recovery.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]

P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

Patient: I didn't know that. Were there any complications during my treatment?
Doctor: No significant complications were recorded during your treatment, which is good news. However, I noticed that there were no PT/OT notes or follow-up recorded. 
Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?
Doctor: PT/OT refers to physical therapy and occupational therapy. It's important to have these sessions and follow-ups to ensure proper recovery and regain function in your injured knee. 
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what should I do now?
Doctor: I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a physical therapist and an occupational therapist to assess your current condition and create a plan for your ongoing recovery.
Patient: Alright, I'll do that. Thanks for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out. Take care and wishing you a speedy recovery.

  - Follow any additional instructions or precautions provided by the healthcare team.
  - Monitor for any signs of complications or worsening symptoms.
  - Contact the healthcare team if any concerns or questions arise.

1. What are the potential complications of an electrical burn?
Solution: Potential complications of an electrical burn include infection, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, electrolyte imbalances, and nerve damage.

2. Explain the purpose of a skin grafting procedure in the treatment of an electrical burn.
Solution: Skin grafting is a surgical procedure where healthy skin is taken from one area of the body (donor site) and transplanted to the burned area (recipient site). The purpose of skin grafting in the treatment of an electrical burn is to promote wound healing, protect the underlying tissues from infection, and restore the appearance of the burned area.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I understand you recently presented to an outside institution with an acute episode of aphasia. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yeah, it was quite sudden. I had difficulty speaking and understanding what others were saying.
Doctor: I see. The MR-imaging that was performed revealed an enhancing left temporal mass, with a maximum enhancing diameter of 2.1 cm (Fig.). The biopsy of the lesion showed that it was histologically consistent with GBM. The test results were IDH1R132H negative, 1p/19q intact, MGMT unmethylated, p53 positive, and without EGFR amplification. 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: To treat this, you underwent LITT, which involved an energy of 24.42 kJ, 876 pulses, and a time of 0:29:07. The treatment was done using a single track approximately 4 cm in length. You were discharged home on post-treatment day 2 at your neurological baseline. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: About two weeks after LITT, you came to our institution with complaints of increasing headache and calculation difficulties, despite being on corticosteroid therapy. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, the headaches were getting worse, and I had trouble doing simple math.
Doctor: I understand. The MR-imaging we did revealed tissue necrosis with hemorrhagic material within the LITT treated region and edema surrounding the treatment site. To address this, you underwent en bloc resection of the enhancing lesion and adjacent tumor-infiltrated brain via a left temporal craniotomy (Fig.). Your headache and calculation difficulties resolved after the surgery and you were discharged on post-operative day 2. 
Patient: Yes, I felt much better after the surgery.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Post-operative MR-imaging confirmed complete resection of the enhancing lesion. You also underwent adjuvant radiation therapy and were treated to a dose of 5945 cGy in 29 fractions with concurrent temozolomide. However, the maintenance temozolomide was discontinued after 5 cycles due to persistent pancytopenia.
Patient: Yeah, I remember that.
Doctor: Interestingly, there has been no surgical or medical treatment for the past 4 years, and serial MR imaging since the surgery has shown no recurrence of your disease.
Patient: That's really good news!
Doctor: Yes, it is. I also wanted to let you know that the gross specimen from your surgery was 6.5 cm in the anteroposterior and 4.4 cm in the mediolateral dimensions. The histological examination revealed a thermal injury pattern characterized by 3 distinct staining patterns in relation to the different zones of the lesion. This included a central necrotic zone (Zone 1) devoid of cells (Fig. a).
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: Moving forward, we will continue to monitor your condition closely with regular MR imaging. If you experience any new symptoms or have concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate all your help and care.

S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello there, can you please tell me why you have come in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm a 13-year-old boy and I've been experiencing headaches, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 weeks.
Doctor: I see. Let's take a closer look at your condition. We performed a Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of your brain and spinal cord, which revealed a left cerebellar expansive lesion. However, there is no evidence of metastasis.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We also conducted a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination, and fortunately, there is no evidence of dissemination. You underwent complete surgical resection as confirmed by postoperative imaging to remove the lesion.
Patient: So the surgery went well then?
Doctor: Yes, the surgery was successful. After that, we performed a histopathological analysis, including reticulin staining, which revealed a desmoplastic/nodular MB. There was no diffuse severe cytological anaplasia present.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that the tumor is a specific type, and it's not as aggressive as some other types. We also performed complementary immunophenotypic characterization, which suggested a MB with SHH activation and TP53 wild-type. The nuclear INI-1 staining was preserved, and P53 immunostaining showed nuclear positivity only in a small proportion of the tumor cells.
Patient: Okay, I hope that's a good sign.
Doctor: Yes, it is. There was no evidence of MYCN or MYCC amplification by fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH). We conducted next-generation sequencing (NGS) over a panel of 50 genes using the Ion AmpliSeq™ Cancer Hotspot Panel v2, which revealed an IDH1 R132C mutation in 46% of cells.
Patient: What about the other genes?
Doctor: We repeated the NGS with a panel of 400 genes using the Ion AmpliSeq™ Comprehensive Cancer Panel, and it revealed IDH1 R132C mutation in 24% of cells, SMARCB1-R201G in 30% of cells, and CDH11-L625T in 26% of cells. The panel was tested on both tumor and normal tissue to confirm the somatic nature of the mutations.
Patient: Were there any other mutations detected?
Doctor: No, mutations in SMO, PTCH1, SUFU, and TP53 were not detected. The Infinium Methylation EPIC BeadChip (850k) array revealed the highest resemblance to the methylation class MB, subclass SHH A (children and adult). The calibrated score further supported these findings.
Patient: So what's the next step, doctor?
Doctor: We will continue to monitor your condition closely and provide any necessary follow-up care. Since the surgery was successful and the tumor type is less aggressive, there is reason to be optimistic about your prognosis.
Patient: Thank you, doctor, for explaining everything to me. I appreciate your help.

A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you were referred to our hospital for further investigation of elevated liver enzyme levels and thrombocytopenia. Can you tell me about your medical history and any symptoms you've been experiencing lately?
Patient: Well, I don't have any significant medical history. But for the past few days, I've been feeling general malaise and noticed some purpura on my legs. I haven't had a fever or any abdominal complaints though.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. I also see that you have a history of alcohol intake, about 40g per day. Have you been taking any constant medications or drugs?
Patient: No, I haven't been taking any drugs or medications.
Doctor: Okay, let's review your vital signs and laboratory findings. Your vital signs are stable, but you have jaundice and purpura on your legs. The laboratory results show total bilirubin at 8.8 mg/dL, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) at 1,767 U/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) at 1,845 U/L, γ-glutamyl transpeptidase at 2,229 U/L, alkaline phosphatase (ALP) at 845 U/L, and immunoglobulin G (IgG) at 2,042 mg/dl. Your anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) titer is positive at 80-fold dilution, and your platelet count is 22,000/μL. 
Patient: Hmm, that's a lot of numbers. What do they mean?
Doctor: These numbers suggest that there might be an issue with your liver. We also tested for hepatitis A, B, C, and E viruses, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, varicella zoster virus, and herpes simplex virus, all of which were negative. However, your anti-Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) IgG was positive.
Patient: So, what's the issue with my liver?
Doctor: We performed abdominal ultrasonography and enhanced computed tomography, which didn't reveal any significant biliary tract disease that could have led to liver damage. Based on the International Autoimmune Hepatitis Scoring System, your pretreatment clinical score without histology is 13. This indicates probable autoimmune hepatitis (AIH). Your severe thrombocytopenia is likely due to concomitant immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) based on your clinical and laboratory findings.
Patient: Oh, I see. What's the next step?
Doctor: We will need to perform a liver biopsy to get a clearer understanding of your condition. After that, we can discuss the appropriate treatment options for both autoimmune hepatitis and immune thrombocytopenic purpura.
Patient: Alright, thank you for explaining everything. I appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask. We will do our best to help you manage your condition.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you're an 86-year-old white male ex-smoker with dyslipidemia. Can you tell me about your prior medical history?
Patient: Sure, I had neuralgia of the trigeminal nerve, prostatism, and nephrolithiasis. I also had a history of coronary artery disease.
Doctor: I see. You previously underwent cardiac catheterization in 1986, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. They found atheromatosis and 30% stenosis of my right coronary, circumflex, and anterior descending arteries.
Doctor: And you've had endovascular treatment for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in 2010 and an aneurysm of the left internal iliac in 2014, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: In March 2016, did you experience progressive effort dyspnea?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: You underwent cardiac catheterization for suspected non-angina myocardial ischemia. The results showed atheromatous lesions involving 50% of the proximal third of the anterior descending artery, 80% of the mid third, 30% of the proximal third of the circumflex artery, and 50% of the proximal third, 90% of the mid third, 50% of the distal third of the right coronary artery. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: After that, you had angioplasty conducted in two stages with a 2-week interval. Diagnostic catheterization and stent angioplasty were performed, with a total of three accesses, all via the left radial access, since the diagnostic procedure revealed occlusion of the right brachial artery related to prior catheterization. How did you feel after the angioplasty?
Patient: My symptoms improved significantly after the angioplasty.
Doctor: But a year after the intervention, you began experiencing dyspnea again, this time unrelated to effort. You underwent investigation again in March 2017. Do you recall the results of the electrocardiogram?
Patient: I think it showed a sinusoidal rhythm with a frequency of 57.
Doctor: Yes, and the stress echocardiogram with an ejection fraction at 55% did not reveal evidence of ischemia or fibrosis. Polysomnography found an apnea-hypopnea index of 3.8, with oxyhemoglobin saturation varying from 76 to 91% while asleep. Spirometry results showed forced vital capacity within expected limits and airflow mildly reduced, with significant variations on the bronchodilator test. Based on these findings, we'll work together to manage your symptoms and monitor your condition closely. It's important to follow up with regular appointments and report any new symptoms or changes.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I've been having a stomachache and loss of appetite for more than a month now.
Doctor: I see. Have you been admitted to a hospital for this issue before?
Patient: Yes, I was admitted to Fukui General Hospital.
Doctor: Do you have any significant medical or family history we should know about?
Patient: No, my medical and family history are unremarkable.
Doctor: Have you smoked or consumed alcohol heavily in the past?
Patient: I smoked ten cigarettes a day from the age of 20 to 67 years and had heavy alcohol consumption for 10 years or longer, but I've stopped drinking now.
Doctor: Okay. During your physical examination at Fukui General Hospital, did they find any anemia, edema, or malnutrition?
Patient: No, they didn't find any of those.
Doctor: Were there any abnormalities in your laboratory data, such as tumor markers like carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), carbohydrate antigen 19-9, SCC antigen, or CA125?
Patient: No, they didn't find any abnormalities in those either.
Doctor: I see. What did the endoscopic examination reveal?
Patient: It showed an ulcerated tumor in my lower esophagus, 33 cm from the incisors.
Doctor: Did they determine the type of carcinoma from the biopsy specimens?
Patient: They said it was a poorly differentiated carcinoma without any features of differentiation, suggesting poorly differentiated SCC or undifferentiated carcinoma.
Doctor: What did the upper gastrointestinal fluoroscopy show?
Patient: It revealed a transdiaphragmatic, circular ulcerative tumor that measured 7 cm along its major axis.
Doctor: Were there any findings from the enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan?
Patient: It showed a swollen lymph node along the left paracardiac region and the left gastric artery. No distant metastasis was detected.
Doctor: Based on these findings, a preoperative clinical diagnosis of T3N1M0 stage III cancer was made using the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) classification system. What treatment did you undergo?
Patient: I underwent a lower esophageal resection and total gastrectomy with lymph node dissection in December 2008.
Doctor: How was your recovery?
Patient: I had an uneventful recovery.
Doctor: Did you receive any adjuvant chemotherapy?
Patient: Yes, I had three courses of 5-fluorouracil (5FU) plus cis-diamminedichloroplatinum (CDDP) and oral tegafur-uracil (UFT) for 1 year following surgery.
Doctor: And how has your health been since then?
Patient: I'm doing well, I haven't shown any recurrence for 10 years.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Make sure to keep up with regular checkups and inform us if you experience any new symptoms.
generated_soap:
S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

Exercise 1:
What is the purpose of a SOAP note?
Answer: The purpose of a SOAP note is to record the subjective, objective, assessment, and plan of a patient's medical history, physical examination, and treatment.

Exercise 2:
What are the four main components of a SOAP note?
Answer: The four main components of a SOAP note are Subjective, Objective, Assessment, and Plan.

Exercise 3:
How is a SOAP note different from a regular medical report?
Answer: A SOAP note is different from a regular medical report because it focuses on the patient's history, physical examination, and treatment, while a regular medical report may also include other information such as diagnostic tests and procedures.

Exercise 4:
Imagine you are a medical assistant and you need to take a patient's medical history. What information would you include in the SOAP note?
Answer: In the SOAP note, I would include the patient's complaints, past medical history, family history, lifestyle habits, and any other relevant information that may impact their current health.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: I presented to the emergency room with sudden right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting.
Doctor: I see. Let me perform a physical exam to check for any signs of appendicitis. Have you experienced any similar symptoms in the past?
Patient: Yes, five years ago I had diffuse abdominal pain and a CT scan identified a lesion in my small bowel. The endoscopic biopsy showed it was GIST.
Doctor: Did you undergo any treatment for that?
Patient: I had a resection without complications. No pathology was available, and according to me, no adjuvant chemotherapy was given. I was symptom-free for the next several years.
Doctor: Thank you for the information. I'll need to perform some tests to check for any signs of recurrence. In the meantime, I'll also check your white blood cell count.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
[later]
Doctor: Your white blood cell count is elevated at 16.5, and the CT scan shows signs of appendicitis as well as suspicious masses in the abdominal area. We'll need to consider nonoperative management and further workup. Let's have a discussion about the next steps.
Patient: What do you think might be happening?
Doctor: Based on the findings, the right lower quadrant masses are most concerning for recurrent GIST. We'll need to perform a diagnostic laparoscopy to confirm this and plan for surgery.
Patient: Okay, let's do the surgery.
[later, after surgery]
Doctor: I wanted to update you on the surgery. During the diagnostic laparoscopy, we found that the appendix wall was thickened and acutely inflamed with nodular lesions. We also found multiple nodules on the terminal ileum and the parietal peritoneum of the anterior and lateral abdominal walls.
Patient: Were you able to remove them all?
Doctor: We removed most of them, but one larger nodule in the right pelvis couldn't be mobilized. Due to the volume of the separate masses, we had to convert the case to a laparotomy. We made a lower midline incision, secured the mesoappendix with a stapler, and resected the appendix.
Patient: What about the other nodules and the terminal ileum?
Doctor: We removed all visible nodules from the peritoneum and performed a partial resection of the terminal ileum. We'll need to closely monitor your recovery and follow up with any additional treatments as necessary.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.

Topic: Medical, Health, and Drugs

Essay Exercise on Topic: Psychology--Social--Attribution Theory

Attribution theory is a psychological concept that explains how individuals interpret and explain the behavior of others. It is a fundamental aspect of social psychology, as it helps us understand how we perceive and make sense of the actions of those around us. In this essay, we will explore the concept of attribution theory and its significance in our daily lives.

According to attribution theory, individuals tend to attribute the behavior of others to either internal or external factors. Internal factors refer to personal characteristics or traits, while external factors refer to situational or environmental influences. For example, if someone fails a test, they may attribute their failure to their lack of intelligence (internal) or the difficulty of the test (external).

One of the key components of attribution theory is the fundamental attribution error. This refers to our tendency to overemphasize internal factors and underestimate external factors when explaining the behavior of others. For instance, if someone cuts us off in traffic, we may assume they are a rude and aggressive person (internal) rather than considering the possibility that they may be in a rush or distracted (external).

The knowledge from the paragraph can be used to support the argument that attribution theory is a crucial aspect of our social interactions. It helps us understand why we may react differently to the same situation based on our interpretation of the behavior of others. For example, if someone is rude to us, we may attribute their

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're an 11-year-old female who presented to the emergency department and was admitted to the hospital in October 2016 with a 1-month history of extreme right lower extremity burning pain and seizure-like activity. Can you describe your symptoms and how frequently they occur?
Patient: Yeah, my right leg has been hurting really badly, and I have these seizure-like episodes. They've been happening like 25 to 30 times a day and last for 2 to 3 minutes each.
Doctor: I understand. The MRI of your back and leg were negative, except for inflammation noted in the ligaments around your right knee. We also performed an EEG because of the frequent seizure-like activity, but it was negative, so the diagnosis is pseudoseizures. We've tried treating your pain with several drugs, including Toradol, Motrin, Tylenol, Oxycontin, and even IV morphine. Have these medications provided any relief?
Patient: No, they haven't really helped with the pain or the seizures.
Doctor: I see. We also evaluated psychogenic causes and looked into your children's hospital records. They suggested reflex sympathetic dystrophy, which was considered due to alterations in the color and temperature of your right leg and evidence of inflammation in the peri-knee ligaments. Videos taken of you show severe pain and seizure activity. After 3 months of these unrelenting symptoms, you've come to my office. We've obtained informed consent to try ozone therapy using direct intravenous gas (DIV). We'll start with five treatments per week, for 26 weeks, totaling 120 treatments. You'll begin therapy at 5 cc gas at a concentration of 55 μg/cc and gradually increase to 30 cc at 55 μg/cc. 
Patient: Okay, I hope this helps.
Doctor: After about 10 sessions, we should see some improvement in your pain and a decrease in pseudoseizures from 25 to 30 per day to 12-15 per day, lasting half the previous average time of 2-3 minutes. 
Patient: That would be a relief.
Doctor: After 3 months, the pseudoseizures should become rare, and by the 4th month, they should stop completely, along with the clearance of all pain. You should be able to return to school symptom-free 1 year after it began and remain symptom-free since.
Patient: That would be amazing. I just want to get back to my normal life.
Doctor: I understand, and we'll do our best to help you achieve that. We'll monitor your progress throughout the ozone therapy treatments to ensure everything is going as planned.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I really appreciate your help.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll work together to get you feeling better and back to living a pain-free life. If you have any concerns during the treatment process, please don't hesitate to reach out to me.
Patient: I will. Thanks again.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

1. What are some potential risks or side effects of ozone therapy?
Solution:

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I see from your history that you've had HTLV-1 infection for 20 years, along with coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes type-2, peripheral vascular disease, chronic neck and back pain, and you've been nonambulatory for a year. You were admitted to the medical service due to dehydration and acute kidney injury. How have you been feeling lately?
Patient: I've been feeling really weak and experiencing worsening pain in my legs. I also have this strange tingling sensation.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. We consulted neurology for your symptoms, and they performed a neurological examination to evaluate for HTLV-1 myelopathy, which can cause pain, stiffness, and gait problems. The examination showed a flat, mask-like face with a positive glabellar reflex. They also found decreased power bilaterally in your upper and lower extremities, brisk reflexes, and hypertonia. Can you tell me more about your muscle strength and any tremors you may have experienced?
Patient: Sure, my arm strength feels like it's 4 out of 5 and I've noticed some shaking when I try to do things. My leg strength is really low, maybe 2 out of 5.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. The examination also found brisk reflexes and bilateral clonus in your lower extremities, as well as bilaterally upgoing toes. The sensory examination was normal, but there was generalized diffuse rigidity. We performed some imaging tests, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of your brain, which showed bilateral basal ganglia calcifications and mild cortical atrophy. We also did magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which revealed low signal intensity from iron accumulation in the red nucleus and substantia nigra, as well as atrophy of the cerebral cortex and superior vermis of the cerebellum. The MRI of the thoracolumbar spine and magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) were unremarkable.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also tested your serum for HTLV-1 antibody, which was positive by enzyme immunoassay (EIA), and your glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD65) antibody was also positive at 8 IU/ml by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Based on the clinical evaluation, it appears that you have HTLV-1 related myelopathy with parkinsonism.
Patient: That sounds serious. What's the plan for treatment?
Doctor: We're going to start you on a trial of two medications: baclofen and Sinemet® (carbidopa-levodopa). These should help improve your symptoms and overall condition. We'll monitor your progress closely and make any necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and hope these medications will make a difference.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to help you manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns along the way.

Follow-up exercises:
1. What are the potential side effects of baclofen and Sinemet® (carbidopa-levodopa) that the medical assistant should inform the patient about?

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 58-year-old male with no past medical history. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Hi doc, I've been experiencing left lower extremity weakness for the past 30 minutes. All of a sudden, my leg just felt paralyzed, so I decided to come here for an evaluation.
Doctor: I understand. Have you noticed any other symptoms along with the weakness?
Patient: Hmm, now that you mention it, I've also been having central chest pain that seems to spread to my back. It started around the same time as the paralysis.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. And have you experienced any shortness of breath or other neurological deficits?
Patient: No, just the weakness in my leg and the chest pain.
Doctor: Alright. When you arrived at the emergency department, we noticed that you were pale, diaphoretic, and in acute distress. Your vital signs at the time were a pulse of 74 beats per minute, blood pressure of 166/97 millimeters of mercury in the right upper extremity, respirations of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, and an oral temperature of 97.9 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Doctor: Upon physical exam, we found bilateral diminished radial pulses and 0/5 strength in your left lower extremity. Your lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there was no appreciable murmur. We didn't obtain a chest radiograph (CXR) at this time.
Doctor: We performed an electrocardiogram (ECG) which demonstrated an acute inferior and posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). This prompted us to activate a "code STEMI." However, before proceeding, we also performed a POCUS ultrasound.
Doctor: The ultrasound revealed right ventricle akinesis consistent with an acute MI and a dissection flap of the aortic arch. However, it was negative for pericardial effusion or tamponade. Based on these ultrasound findings and with cardiology at bedside, we decided to cancel the "code STEMI."
Doctor: Instead of percutaneous coronary intervention, we have decided that you need emergent cardiothoracic surgery. We immediately brought you to the radiology suite for an emergent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest and abdomen to further evaluate your condition.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious situation, and we are doing our best to provide you with the appropriate care.
Doctor: Unfortunately, while on the table prior to the imaging acquisition, you became bradycardic. We're monitoring you closely and will proceed with the necessary interventions as needed.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in this difficult situation.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will continue to provide you with the best care possible and keep you and your family informed of any updates in your condition. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

Dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 58-year-old male with no past medical history. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Hi doc, I've been experiencing left lower extremity weakness for the past 30 minutes. All of a sudden, my leg just felt paralyzed, so I decided to come here for an evaluation.
Doctor: I understand. Have you noticed any other symptoms along with the weakness?
Patient: Hmm, now that you mention it, I've also been having central chest pain that seems to spread to my back. It started around the same time as the paralysis.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. And have you experienced any shortness of breath or other neurological deficits?
Patient: No, just the weakness in my leg and the chest pain.
Doctor: Alright. When you arrived at the emergency department, we noticed that you were pale, diaphoretic, and in acute distress. Your vital signs at the time were a pulse of 74 beats per minute, blood pressure of 166/97 millimeters of mercury in the right upper extremity, respirations of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, and an oral temperature of 97.9 degrees Fahrenheit. 
Doctor: Upon physical exam, we found bilateral diminished radial pulses and 0/5 strength in your left lower extremity. Your lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there was no appreciable murmur. We didn't obtain a chest radiograph (CXR) at this time.
Doctor: We performed an electrocardiogram (ECG) which demonstrated an acute inferior and posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). This prompted us to activate a "code STEMI." However, before proceeding, we also performed a POCUS ultrasound.
Doctor: The ultrasound revealed right ventricle akinesis consistent with an acute MI and a dissection flap of the aortic arch. However, it was negative for pericardial effusion or tamponade. Based on these ultrasound findings and with cardiology at bedside, we decided to cancel the "code STEMI."
Doctor: Instead of percutaneous coronary intervention, we have decided that you need emergent cardiothoracic surgery. We immediately brought you to the radiology suite for an emergent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest and abdomen to further evaluate your condition.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is a serious situation, and we are doing our best to provide you with the appropriate care.
Doctor: Unfortunately, while on the table prior to the imaging acquisition, you became bradycardic. We're monitoring you closely and will proceed with the necessary interventions as needed.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help in this difficult situation.
Doctor: You're welcome. We will continue to provide you with the best care possible and keep you and your family informed of any updates in your condition. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

SOAP Note:
S: 
- Patient is a 58-year-old male with no past medical history.
- Patient presents to the emergency department with acute left lower extremity weakness and central chest pain.
- Patient reports no shortness of breath or other neurological deficits.
- Patient is in acute distress, pale, diaphoretic, and has a pulse of 74 beats per minute, blood pressure of 166/97 millimeters of mercury in the right upper extremity, respirations of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 97% on room air, and an oral temperature of 97.9 degrees Fahrenheit.
O: 
- Patient has bilateral diminished radial pulses and 0/5 strength in the left lower extremity.
- Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
- No appreciable murmur is heard.
- Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates an acute inferior and posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).
- POCUS ultrasound reveals right ventricle akinesis consistent with an acute MI and a dissection flap of the aortic arch.
- No pericardial effusion or tamponade is detected.
- Cardiology is consulted and a decision is made to cancel the "code STEMI."
- Patient is brought to the radiology suite for an emergent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the chest and abdomen.
A: 
- Patient has a diagnosis of acute inferior and posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) with a dissection flap of the aortic arch.
- Patient requires emergent cardiothoracic surgery.
- Patient is monitored for bradycardia and other complications.
P: 
- Patient will undergo emergent cardiothoracic surgery.
- Patient will be closely monitored for any changes in condition.
- Patient will be kept informed of any updates in their condition.

Solution: The POCUS ultrasound findings showed right ventricle akinesis consistent with an acute MI and a dissection flap of the aortic arch. This information is crucial in guiding the decision to cancel the "code STEMI" and proceed with emergent cardiothoracic

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you are a 48-year-old employed male, and you have been diagnosed with bipolar 1 disorder. You were recently admitted to our inpatient psychiatric unit for the treatment of severe bipolar 1 depression. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. About two months ago, I was involuntarily hospitalized at another facility for mania.
Doctor: I see. Before your admission, we obtained standard laboratory measures, which were within normal limits, and a urine toxicology screen, which was negative. Can you tell me about your symptoms during the initial days on our service?
Patient: Sure. I was feeling really depressed and had low energy. I slept through the night and most of the day. I rarely attended group therapy or socialized with the staff or other patients.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. We started you on modafinil 100 mg daily with plans to use it short term to help combat your hypersomnia. At that time, your psychiatric medications included divalproex 2,500 mg QHS, quetiapine 300 mg QHS, and venlafaxine 225 mg once daily. Venlafaxine had been increased to 225 mg several weeks prior to the initiation of modafinil. Your valproic acid level was 79 ug/ml, confirming adequate prophylactic treatment of mania. There were no other changes made to your medication regimen at this time. Did you notice any changes in your symptoms after we started the modafinil?
Patient: Yeah, two days after starting modafinil, I began to have some weird symptoms, like seeing trees moving in my bedroom and thinking there were cameras in the pictures on my wall. I also thought a water bottle was transmitting something into my room.
Doctor: I see. And did you experience any other psychotic behaviors during that time?
Patient: Yes, I woke up my roommate in the middle of the night, accusing him of abusing his daughter, and later, I accused the treatment team of including me in experimental research.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that information. Following these psychotic events, we decided to discontinue the modafinil, and your psychotic features subsided within the following days. How are you feeling now?
Patient: I'm feeling much better now, thank you.
Doctor: That's great to hear. We will continue to monitor your progress and adjust your treatment plan as needed. If you have any concerns or notice any changes in your symptoms, please let us know immediately.
Patient: Okay, I will. Thank you for your help, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care, and if you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.
generated_soap:
S: [Subjective findings - patient's complaints and history]
O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]
