dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I heard you were referred to our division for a mixed ground-glass opacity lesion in your right upper lung. How are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm feeling fine, actually. I haven't noticed any symptoms.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Your good performance status is a positive sign. We did a physical examination and there were no remarkable findings. We also performed a chest computed tomography (CT) which revealed a 34 mm x 20 mm partial solid nodule with spicule formation and pleural indentation at the right S3 (Fig. ). The consolidation tumor ratio was 30%.
Patient: Oh, okay. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means there is a lesion in your lung, and we need to investigate it further. We conducted a preoperative positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) which showed that the standard uptake value (SUV) of the lesion was 1.9, and there was no suspicious metastasis. 
Patient: That's a relief, I guess.
Doctor: Yes, it's good news that there's no sign of metastasis. We also detected a Kommerell diverticulum at the origin of the left subclavian artery and a right-sided aortic arch through preoperative three-dimensional computed tomography (3D CT) reconstruction (Fig. , ). An echocardiography revealed no cardiac abnormalities.
Patient: So, what's the next step, doc?
Doctor: Considering the lesion might be malignant, we performed a right upper lobectomy. We used a three-port VATS approach with no rib spreading (no soft tissue retractor or direct visualization). We made a 3-cm incision in the fourth intercostal space (ICS) at the anterior axillary line as the main manipulation port, and a 1-cm incision in the seventh ICS at the scapular line as an assisted manipulation port. A 1-cm thoracoscopic port was made in the seventh ICS at the middle axillary line.
Patient: Alright, then what happened?
Doctor: After dividing the interlobar fissure with a linear stapler, we detached and divided the ascending A2, right superior pulmonary vein (RSPV), A1 + A3, and right upper lobe bronchus sequentially. There were no anatomic variations of pulmonary vessels or bronchi (Fig. ). We then histologically confirmed the invasive carcinoma.
Patient: Oh no, that's not good.
Doctor: I understand your concern. We proceeded with a radical mediastinal lymph node dissection to ensure proper treatment. After the routine dissection of the pulmonary ligament lymph node (#9) and the paraesophageal lymph node (#8), we dissected the subcarinal lymph node (#7). It was difficult to expose the left main bronchus, but we managed to complete the procedure.
Patient: What does this mean for my future health, doctor?
Doctor: We will closely monitor your recovery and schedule follow-up appointments to ensure there are no further complications. We will provide you with specific instructions for your post-operative care, and we will be here to support you throughout your recovery.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.

Follow-up Exercise 1:
Explain the significance of the consolidation tumor ratio in the diagnosis and treatment of lung lesions.

Solution to Follow-up Exercise 1:
The consolidation tumor ratio is a measure used to assess the extent of lung involvement in a lung lesion. It is calculated by dividing the volume of the lesion by the total volume of the lung. A higher consolidation tumor ratio indicates a more extensive involvement of the lung tissue. In the case of the patient in the dialogue, a consolidation tumor ratio of 30% suggests that the lesion is occupying a significant portion of the lung. This information is important in determining the appropriate treatment approach and predicting the prognosis of the patient.

Follow-up Exercise 2:
What are the potential complications that can arise from a right upper lobectomy?

Solution to Follow-up Exercise 2:
A right upper lobectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a portion of the right upper lobe of the lung. While it is generally a safe procedure, there are potential complications that can arise. These may include:

1. Ble

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I just wanted to inform you about your son's situation after the accident. He was presented to the emergency department following a high-speed front-end collision with another vehicle. Was he the one driving?
Family: No, he was in the front seat but not driving. He was restrained, thankfully.
Doctor: I see. The vehicle he was in was struck head-on. Do you happen to know the speed at the time of the collision?
Family: We were told it was in excess of 79 miles per hour.
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. When your son arrived at the hospital, he was unconscious and not breathing independently. Our team attempted intubation at the scene, but unfortunately, it was unsuccessful.
Family: Oh no... So what happened next?
Doctor: Sadly, your son was pronounced dead soon after arrival to the hospital. Our deepest condolences to your family.
Family: Thank you, Doctor. This is so difficult for us. What were the findings from the radiographs?
Doctor: The radiographs at the time of the incident noted internal decapitation with AO assimilation specifically between the anterior arch of the atlas and the basiocciput. No fractures were noted, including the odontoid process.
Family: Did he have any past medical or surgical history that could have contributed to this?
Doctor: There was no known past medical or surgical history, and the AO assimilation was unknown to your family. The severity of the collision was the primary factor in this tragic outcome.
Family: We had no idea about the AO assimilation. Thank you for explaining everything to us, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any further questions or need any support, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. Our thoughts are with you and your family during this difficult time.

P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

  - Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
  - Blood pressure: 90/60 mmHg
  - Oxygen saturation: 92%

  - Unconscious patient not breathing independently.
  - No signs of trauma other than the head injury.

  - Blood chemistry: Normal.

A:

- Treatment recommendations:

  - Intensive care monitoring, including continuous pulse oximetry, electrocardiography, and blood pressure monitoring.
  - Consultation with a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and potential surgical intervention.
  - Supportive care, including pain management, respiratory support, and fluid and electrolyte management.
  - Close monitoring for any signs

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having progressive walking difficulties and stiffness in my lower limbs since I was 54. It's more pronounced on the left side.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your previous clinical history and family history?
Patient: They are both unremarkable.
Doctor: Okay. Let me perform a neurological examination to better understand your condition. *After examination* I found proximal upper limb weakness (MRC 4/5 on the left side and 3/5 on the right side) and left lower limb weakness (MRC 4/5). Your muscle tone is preserved, but there's hypotrophy of the upper limb-girdle, upper limb proximal muscles, and left lower limb. I also observed a winged scapula on the right side. Spontaneous fasciculations were detected in the proximal segments of your upper limbs.
Patient: Oh, I see. What about sensory impairment or anything with my cerebellum?
Doctor: No sensory impairment was reported, and your cerebellar examination was unremarkable. Your tendon reflexes were normal at the upper limbs, while knee-jerk and ankle-jerk hyperreflexia were present. No Babinski sign was observed, but exhaustible bilateral ankle clone was observed.
Patient: Hmm, and what about bulbar involvement?
Doctor: No bulbar involvement was present. We also conducted routine laboratory tests like blood cell count, blood glucose, vitamin B12, folate, inflammatory parameters, and immunological tests, and everything was in the normal range. HBsAg and anti-HCV and anti-HIV antibodies, as well as thyroid and parathyroid functions, were normal.
Patient: What about any imaging or cerebrospinal fluid analysis?
Doctor: Your brain and spinal cord imaging were normal, as well as the cerebrospinal fluid analysis.
Patient: Did you find anything on the neuropsychological examination?
Doctor: Yes, there was moderate impairment of executive functions like abstraction, critique, working memory, and planning. Abnormal calculation skills were also noted.
Patient: What about the needle electromyography (EMG) and electroneurography (ENG)?
Doctor: The EMG showed mild signs of chronic neurogenic damage on quadriceps femoris, tibialis anterior, and hand dorsal interosseous muscles. Active denervation was detected in the left tibialis anterior, left quadriceps femoris, and right biceps brachii muscles. The ENG demonstrated a reduction of the compound motor action potential (cMAP) amplitude of the right peroneal nerve.
Patient: I see. What do the motor evoked potentials indicate?
Doctor: The motor evoked potentials indicated that there might be an issue with your central motor pathways. We will need to conduct further tests and evaluations to determine the cause of your symptoms and discuss a treatment plan.
Patient: Okay, thank you for the information. I appreciate your help.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]
P: [Plan - treatment recommendations]

- Normal laboratory tests and imaging.

Exercise: What is the purpose of a SOAP note?
Answer: The purpose of a SOAP note is to document a patient's medical history, physical examination findings, diagnosis, and treatment plan in a standardized format for healthcare professionals to refer to and track the patient's progress.

Exercise: What are the components of a SOAP note?
Answer: The components of a SOAP note are Subjective (patient's complaints and history), Objective (exam results, vitals, test results), Assessment (diagnosis/differential), and Plan (treatment recommendations).

Exercise: In what situations would a medical assistant be responsible for writing a SOAP note?
Answer: A medical assistant may be responsible for writing a SOAP note when they are performing a physical examination, reviewing lab results, or documenting a patient's medical history.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been experiencing some issues like ataxia, tremor, and seizures lately. I'm also worried about my developmental delay.
Doctor: I see. Let's first take a look at your electroencephalogram and other test results to better understand your situation. Have you had those tests done?
Patient: Yes, I have the report right here.
Doctor: Great, let me take a look. Hmm, it shows that your blood ammonia level was >300 μg/dL, which is quite high as the normal range is below 80. Your ornithine levels were 71-86 μM/dL, and homocitrulline levels were 510-643 μM/24 hours. Both of these are also above the normal range.
Patient: Oh no, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Don't worry, we can manage this. I'm going to prescribe you a diet consisting of lactulose, arginine, and protein restriction. This should help in reducing your blood ammonia levels and improving your clinical symptoms.
Patient: Okay, I'll follow the diet. How long should I expect before seeing any improvement?
Doctor: It may take some time, but you should see a reduction in your blood ammonia levels to around 110-140 μg/dL, and you'll likely experience some clinical improvement.
Patient: That's good to hear. I have some more news, I recently found out that I'm pregnant, about 8 weeks along.
Doctor: Congratulations! In that case, we'll need to adjust your dietary protein intake. I'll be increasing it to 1.2-1.3 g/kg/d to ensure proper nutrition for both you and the baby.
Patient: Thank you! I'll make sure to follow the new diet plan.
Doctor: I'm glad to hear that. Let's fast forward a bit. You've had a healthy male infant delivered at 39 weeks' gestation. Congratulations once again!
Patient: Thank you! Was the delivery okay?
Doctor: Yes, the mode of delivery was not disclosed, but during the delivery, your maternal ammonia levels varied from 74 to 215 μg/dL.
Patient: I hope my child will be okay.
Doctor: Upon follow-up at 16 months of age, your child's Bayley Scales showed normal development, which is a good sign. And at age 5, your child had an IQ of 130!
Patient: That's wonderful news! I'm so relieved to hear that.
Doctor: I'm glad to see that both you and your child are doing well. Make sure to continue following your prescribed diet and attend regular check-ups to monitor your progress.
Patient: Thank you so much for your help, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you have any concerns or questions in the future, feel free to reach out. Take care and congratulations once again on your healthy baby.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having abdominal pain for about 2 weeks now, and it's been getting worse. I also noticed some bleeding in my stool.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, fever, or weight loss recently?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Do you have any personal history of medical or surgical diseases? And is there any history of malignant disease in your family?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of medical or surgical diseases, and there's no history of malignant disease in my family either.
Doctor: Okay, let's do an initial clinical observation. *After examining the patient* You appear to be haemodynamically stable. I can feel a painless mass in your periumbilical region, left hypochondrium, and left flank. There's also evidence of low gastrointestinal bleeding, or hematochezia. We'll need to get some tests done to find the cause.
Patient: Alright, what tests do I need?
Doctor: First, let's check your haemoglobin. *After checking* Your initial haemoglobin value at admission is 133 g/dl. We'll also perform an emergency non-total colonoscopy to look for any gastrointestinal lesions that could cause the bleeding.
Patient: Okay, let me know what you find.
Doctor: *After colonoscopy* We didn't find any lesions during the colonoscopy. We'll need to perform an Angio-CT to get more information. *After Angio-CT* The scan showed a large exophytic mass, approximately 20 x 14 x 13 cm, arising from the 4th duodenal segment and first jejunal segment. It has vascularization provided from branches of the upper mesenteric artery, with vascular dilatations inside the tumor and apparent intratumoral bleeding. However, there's no intraperitoneal bleeding.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What are my options?
Doctor: Unfortunately, your condition has deteriorated, and you've become haemodynamically instable with a new episode of low gastrointestinal bleeding. Your haemoglobin value has dropped to 8.6 g/dl, so we'll need to provide fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion.
Patient: I understand. What's the next step?
Doctor: Due to your haemodynamic instability, we'll need to perform an emergency laparotomy. *After surgery* We found a large tumor arising from the first jejunal segment, 2 cm after the duodenal-jejunal flexure. We performed a segmental enterectomy, resecting the mass and adjacent jejunum and the 4th duodenal segment. A side-to-side manual anastomosis was performed between the 3rd duodenal segment and the jejunum.
Patient: How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery went well, and you're now in the post-operative period. There were no complications, and we'll be monitoring your recovery.
Patient: When can I start eating again?
Doctor: You can start oral feeding on the 7th post-operative day. We'll perform a gastrointestinal oral contrast study to confirm the integrity of the anastomosis before allowing you to eat.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance during this difficult time.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll be here to support you throughout your recovery. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.

O: [Objective findings - exam results, vitals, test results]
A: [Assessment - diagnosis/differential]

  - No intraperitoneal bleeding.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I see that you've presented to our emergency department with complaints of nausea and vomiting for four days. I'm sorry to hear that.
Patient: Yes, it's been really difficult to deal with.
Doctor: I understand you were diagnosed with right-sided, multicentric, infiltrating lobular carcinoma of the breast 10 years ago. You were Stage 1A, estrogen receptor positive (ER+), progesterone receptor positive (PR+), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative (HER2-). Is that correct?
Patient: Hmm, yes, that's right.
Doctor: And you had a right mastectomy, with sentinel lymph nodes sampled during surgery, which were negative for metastases. You were also treated with adjuvant anastrozole for five years, and yearly mammograms have been negative for recurrence. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see that one year prior to this presentation, you were evaluated at our hospital for similar complaints of nausea and vomiting. A computed tomography (CT) scan of your abdomen and pelvis on admission revealed a mass-like thickening of the gastric antrum and distension of the proximal stomach. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I do.
Doctor: An upper endoscopy (EGD) was performed, which revealed esophagitis and gastric stenosis. This was dilated using a through-the-scope controlled radial expansion (CRE) balloon, without fluoroscopic guidance. Biopsy of the gastric stenosis revealed gastric mucosa of antral type with minimal chronic inactive gastritis. No morphologic evidence of a Helicobacter pylori infection was detected. Did your symptoms of nausea and vomiting improve following balloon dilation?
Patient: Yes, they did improve after that.
Doctor: Good to hear. You were discharged on a daily proton pump inhibitor. Now, you underwent an endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) 12 weeks later. Gastric stenosis was found at the pylorus and duodenal bulb, which was dilated again with a CRE balloon to a maximum dilation of 13.5 mm. Do you recall this?
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: The EUS also showed diffuse wall thickening of the antrum of the stomach, with the gastric wall measuring up to 11 mm in thickness. Thickening within the deep mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis propria was noted. EUS-guided biopsies were taken. Unfortunately, the biopsies revealed invasive poorly differentiated metastatic breast adenocarcinoma.
Patient: Oh no, that's terrible news.
Doctor: I understand this is difficult to hear. Our team will work closely with you to determine the best course of treatment and provide support throughout the process. We'll do everything we can to help you.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and support.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand that you were diagnosed with infectious cervical tuberculosis on C1 about a year ago, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And you underwent posterior C1-2 screw-plate fixation surgery at a hospital in India. How did you feel after the surgery?
Patient: Initially, my neck pain improved, but over the last nine months, my swallowing function has gradually worsened.
Doctor: I see. You also experienced loss of reduction and progressive dysphagia, along with severe weight loss, right?
Patient: Yes, exactly. I was referred to your hospital because of these issues.
Doctor: Thank you for providing that information. I also see in your medical history that you have hypertension and mild diabetes mellitus, with an HbA1c of 6.2% NGSP. Have you been receiving antitubercular treatment since your diagnosis?
Patient: Yes, I've been taking the prescribed medications from my local hospital.
Doctor: Good to know. Now, let's discuss your current condition. Your height is 165 cm, and your weight is 52 kg, which gives you a BMI of 19. You've lost 25 kg over the past 7 months due to difficulty in swallowing. Are you currently using a nasogastric (NG) tube for feeding?
Patient: Yes, I am. It's been helping me get the nutrition I need.
Doctor: That's important for your recovery. During your neurological examination, we found left dominant proximal arm muscle weakness with atrophy, dysesthesia in distal fingers, and hyperreflexia throughout with bilateral extensor plantar reflex. In your oral examination, we noticed left tongue atrophy and left tongue deviation, consistent with unilateral HNP. Your routine blood work showed a slightly elevated level of C reactive protein (CRP), but the other findings were normal. Does this sound accurate to you?
Patient: Yes, that's what I've been told.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I have Crouzon syndrome and I've been having multiple episodes of epistaxis in the past few days. I also have nasal obstruction and impaired nasal breathing for the past few months.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any other medical history we should be aware of?
Patient: No, the rest of my medical history is free.
Doctor: Alright, let's start with a clinical examination. *Examines patient* I notice a polypoid lesion protruding from your right nostril, asymmetry of your face, and projection of the ipsilateral canine fossa.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: We'll need to perform a computed tomography of your paranasal sinuses to get a clearer picture of what's going on. *Reviews CT results* The CT shows an inhomogeneous soft-tissue mass that completely occupies your right nasal cavity, maxillary sinus, and anterior and posterior ethmoidal cells. The lesion has caused extensive bone remodeling of your right maxillary sinus with complete absence of its anterior wall, erosion of the posterior wall, and entry of the lesion in the pterygopalatine fossa. There's also erosion of the ipsilateral lower and median orbital wall, and entry of the lesion in the orbital cavity. Despite its large size, the lesion seems to be well-defined without invasive characteristics.
Patient: That sounds serious. What do the laboratory tests say?
Doctor: Your routine laboratory tests are within the normal range. We also had a preoperative maxillofacial consultation, which excluded pathology of odontogenic origin.
Patient: What's the next step, then?
Doctor: We'll have you undergo a biopsy under local anesthesia. *Performs biopsy* The findings show nonspecific inflammation. We'll need to perform open surgery under general anesthesia via lateral rhinotomy and medial maxillectomy.
Patient: Okay, let's do it.
*After surgery*
Doctor: The surgery went well. The maxillary sinus mucosa was completely replaced by inflammatory tissue, which we were able to mobilize and dissect free from surrounding tissues within the orbit and pterygopalatine fossa. There was no macroscopic invasion of any neighboring structures. The histopathological examination revealed typical nasal polyposis with a mixed population of eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, and no evidence of fungal invasion.
Patient: What's the postoperative treatment?
Doctor: We'll start you on antibiotic and corticosteroid treatment for a short period. You'll also use local nasal mometasone furoate for 2 months after surgery, and we'll administer intensive saline solution irrigations.
Patient: If I follow this treatment, will my symptoms improve?
Doctor: Yes, following this treatment plan should help alleviate your symptoms. Currently, there are no clinical/radiological signs or symptoms of further complications. We'll monitor your progress closely. If you have any concerns or notice any changes, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
